name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I would like to ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to clarify what constitutes a breach under the activity test.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I think I gave you an answer to this question on Thursday. Did I not provide you with an answer to that? I remember I had a discussion with Senator Neal about the penalty rates for breaches that we did by negotiation in early 1997. The activity test breaches include where a person who is required to satisfy an activity test fails to do so or fails to satisfy any requirements relating to youth allowance activity agreements that apply to the person under subdivision (e) of division 1; where the person has refused or failed without reasonable excuse to accept a suitable offer of employment; where the person refuses or fails without reasonable excuse to provide information in relation to the person's income from remunerative work when required to do so; where the person knowingly or recklessly provides false or misleading information in relation to their income when required to do so. It goes on from there. There is nothing extraordinary about them. They are not what you might be driving at, which I would call administrative breaches.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Minister, you mentioned `failed to satisfy any requirements', and that was fairly early in the list. There were some more deliberate points on the list later on, but failing to satisfy any of the requirements could be a technical breach. I know it says the third breach, but notification of a breach might not actually reach the person. How would a person know, for instance, that they had breached once or twice? For instance, if they breached once and they had been notified but their address was not accurate, could it not be possible that they could breach more than once and not know that they had breached?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Senator, I do not think you could have been in the chamber when this was all discussed very thoroughly.
—I was in the chamber.
—Not just last Thursday but also when we were changing the requirements for breaches a year or more ago. You will recall that under the previous government people were breached by losing their payment immediately regardless. We have changed that. We negotiated that with the parties in the Senate last year to a rate reduction for a number of weeks for the first penalty, a bigger rate reduction for the second penalty and only on the third breach do people lose all payment altogether. Have you forgotten that?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I think it was established during those debates, however, that some of those breaches could have still been technical breaches. Even though a person lost their benefit, there may still be something which was out of the person's control. What I am specifically asking about is whether there is any discretion involved here. If there was no discretion involved in the previous applications of the term penalties or breaches, how can you say that a person will not be treated unfairly? Is there any discretion involved in the definition of breaches? Can a person judge—even if there are three breaches— 
 whether or not a person has been treated fairly?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I think Senator Margetts, in talking about technical breaches, is referring to administrative breaches which are regarded as a lesser order, like not returning a form on time, for example. There is no discretion, as I understand it, as to whether something is determined to be an administrative breach, which gets a lesser penalty, and an activity test breach, which has the penalties that I just spelled out to you. It is very important to understand that there are two kinds of breaches: one is less serious and the other group is more serious.
The officers do not have an opportunity to distinguish between those two. If it is an administrative breach, one lot of rules apply. If it is an activity test breach, another lot of rules apply. Within that area people who are not satisfied with the decision of the determining officer have the right to ask for a review, which is done by an authorised review officer, an ARO. If that is still not satisfactory, people can then go to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —The minister is indicating that, without any means of support, a person may be expected to ask for a review. How long would the review take?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —Mr Chairman, I think it must be made very clear to Senator Margetts that, as compared with the past, people are not now—with unemployment payments, for example—being left with no means support, unless it is the third time they have broken the law.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I really do not feel that the minister's answer has been satisfactory. If there is no ability for discretion, you will find—and I know the courts in Western Australia who have `three strikes and you are out' legislation find it extremely difficult when an arbitrary number is pulled out of the air with it being said, `Okay, if you've done something three times, you must be punished in a certain way,' and this is punitive—there 
 will always, always be circumstances where, no matter how many times you arbitrarily decide, there will be people for whom no one of those breaches is their fault; that there are reasons why they were unable to avoid those things.
There are reasons sometimes of poverty, there are reasons of family tragedy. There are a whole range of reasons, of circumstances, where pulling out an arbitrary number of three times will be unfair if there are no discretions. And, if there are no discretions, what is the basis upon which a person might appeal?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —There is discretion and in the sorts of circumstances you are talking about—like family tragedy, illness, et cetera—the officers are entitled to use that discretion. Senator, you were part of this chamber that put that measure through last year as a non-controversial piece of legislation.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I am actually referring to the part in this bill in relation to the activity test breach; I asked you a little while ago, `Was it discretionary?' and you said no. That is what I am referring to.
—As between the two kinds of breaches.
—The minister is saying that there is a different sort of breach, but in this instance, the minister is saying that it is not discretionary. I am asking: on what basis, for a non-discretionary clause to be in this bill, would a person be able to appeal?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Mr Chairman, I do not think Senator Margetts listened carefully to the answer. There are activity breaches which are the more serious ones and carry a more serious penalty, and there are administrative breaches which are considered to be less serious and carry a less serious penalty. So it is determined by law which is which.
—You are writing the law.
—However, Senator—if you would listen instead of jumping to 
 conclusions—within each of those two areas of breaches, the departmental officials are able to exercise their discretion. There is also, as I pointed out to you, an extensive review mechanism. I think that the Senate regarded that as fair. You are saying to me that we are talking about this legislation. Yes, we are. But it is mirroring the legislation that the Senate signed on to last year as a piece of non-controversial legislation. So I find it strange that you are revisiting an issue that the Senate has already passed judgment on.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I think Senator Newman may be stepping on very dangerous ground if she starts talking about non-controversial legislation, when I am basically abused nearly every time the Greens have problems with a piece of so-called non-controversial legislation which often we have not had much chance to look at.
So, if at any time we pass something through and are asked sometimes to have about two or three days to look at a piece of legislation, if then you are going to come back and say, `You agreed to it because we passed it through quickly in a lunchtime,' then I would suggest that you do not try to do that; you will not get any more pieces of legislation through at lunchtime. If we do not get a chance to look carefully at legislation, then it is quite reasonable for the Greens to say, `No, we're not going to do them in lunchtimes.' If you are then going to turn around to us and say, `We gave you a lunchtime to look at it,' or `We gave you this amount of time; we pleaded with you because we want it in a non-controversial Thursday,' I think you are stepping on very dangerous ground.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I think Senator Margetts cannot have taken any notice or any interest in the issue when it came before the Senate last time. It came about that that legislation was changed because, in the debate in December 1996, Senator Harradine suggested that he could see that all the parties around the chamber were trying to grasp at a solution which would be fairer than the system we inherited, which 
 took people off payments altogether regardless of their offence. We were agreeable to that. So we did as was suggested by Senator Harradine. We went around to the parties with some proposals, and we negotiated the final outcome of that piece of non-controversial legislation which was passed by the Senate with due process.
Now, suddenly, you are just discovering it. I am sorry about that. But what we have in this legislation is a mirror image of what the Senate thoughtfully decided upon previously.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —If Senator Newman is suggesting that the Greens (WA) agreeing to an improvement on something that was bad means that we still agree with the bad points or unfair points of the legislation, that is not true. If you want to continue on with this kind of nonsense argument, Senator, please do. But please do not assume that, when we vote for an improvement on something that is ghastly, that means we believe that the ghastly thing is okay.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —The Democrats will be supporting the Greens (WA) amendment in relation to the substitution of two weeks instead of eight weeks. Although I take on board the senator's comments about previous legislative changes in relation to the breach period, we do note that when the government first came to power the penalty for the breach of the activity test was two to six weeks for a first breach, and then subsequent breaches attracted a penalty of the period of the first breach plus an additional six weeks. So we prefer the amendment as put forward by the Greens WA.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I do want to make a few comments about this amendment and also about a view expressed by the minister when we were here on Thursday afternoon. There was some discussion when the breaches of the activity test were first put in place. But I thought it was going a little bit far to say that there was an `agreement', as if it were an initiative jointly of the government and the opposition.
It would be more accurate to say that the government proposed penalties for breaches of the activity test we found quite unacceptable. I suppose we were happy that the government was agreeable to negotiating a penalty that was less severe. To some extent we negotiated down the initial penalty. I suppose it can be described as agreement, but probably not to the full extent that might have been drawn from what the minister said. Certainly, the ultimate result was brought about by negotiation between the opposition, the government and other members.
Bearing that in mind, the opposition does not intend to support this amendment. We do see it as obviously a balance between ensuring that the penalties are not so severe that people find their circumstances quite untenable, and ensuring that people accept that they do have a responsibility to comply with the requirements for the payment of their benefits or their benefits will be suspended for a period.
We believed at the time of the negotiation that this was a reasonable balance. Nothing has occurred that has altered our minds on this and accordingly we will not be supporting these changes.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Can I ask the minister a simple question, and forgive me if it is too simple? My understanding is that under this bill people could void the non-payment period by taking up work under the work for the dole program. Would those people presumably be included in the voluntary work for the dole participants?
—I am advised that for young people who go into the work for the dole scheme, whether it is voluntary or whether it is because they are directed to, if they have a breach penalty outstanding, that is waived.
—I am just assuming that those people, by virtue of volunteering to void the non-payment period, would be included in the voluntary numbers. Presumably, if they volunteer to get involved for whatever reason, including voiding that 
 non-payment period, they would be included in the voluntary work for the dole.
—I am advised that that is that DEETYA classification and we are really not in a position to be able to give you a precise answer. I have given you the best answer that I can at this stage.
—The question is that the request for an amendment be agreed to.
Request not agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I move:
(10)	 Schedule 1, item 6, page 52 (after line 29), after subsection 550C(1), insert:
(1A)	 A notice under subsection (1) must contain reasons why the activity test non-payment period applies to the person.
This amendment requires the secretary to provide reasons why the person is about to be cut off the youth allowance. The minister mentioned that it is possible for people to appeal and how awfully fair and reasonable it all is. So it is not the least bit unreasonable to suggest that, if a person is about to be cut off their youth allowance, they should be given the reasons why.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The government will accept Senator Margetts' amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(12)	 Schedule 1, item 6, page 65 (lines 25 and 26), omit "one or more of sections 553A to 553C", substitute "either or both of sections 553B and 553C".
(13)	 Schedule 1, item 6, page 66 (line 1) to page 67 (line 4), omit section 553A.
This amendment refers to clause 553A, subsection (2) of the bill on page 66, which states:
If:
(a)	 a person's unemployment was due to other people being, or having been, engaged in industrial act or in a series of industrial actions; and 

(b)	 the people, or some of the people, were members of a trade union that was involved in the industrial action;
the person is subject to an employment-related exclusion unless the person satisfies the Secretary that the person was not a member of the trade union during the person's period of the unemployment.
I find that a fairly discriminatory clause. Basically, it says that, if there has been industrial action which has caused a person to lose their job or to be unemployed, they are going to be punished. Not only have they been disadvantaged from losing their job or because they felt it necessary to take industrial action—so there must be have been some problem to start with—but they are going to be punished for being involved with a union or being a member of a union. There is the word `and' in here. It states:
. . . the people, or some of the people, were members of a trade union that was involved in the industrial action;. . .
The minister will no doubt say that there are other bills to which this applies. We think this stinks, whichever bill you put it in.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—This is mirroring an existing provision which has been presided over by the last Labor government for the last 13 years. The presence of the trade union reference is not new to us. Our legislation is simply replicating the provisions in the newstart allowance legislation, with some minor changes due to the different qualification conditions.
Also it is not believed that it will affect significant numbers of people as most people will return to work after industrial action. The point about the preclusion period which I think is important to understand is that it applies only to industrial action which is in breach of an order, direction or injunction issued by a state industrial authority, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court. So, it is only if the industrial action is in breach of that that this period applies.
Before the six-week preclusion period was introduced difficulties used to arise in determining the exact reasons for a person's unemployment while the issues surrounding 
 the industrial action remained unresolved. Now the preclusion period allows resolution of issues. This is simply a transfer of the provisions in the newstart allowance legislation that we inherited into youth allowance. There is nothing particularly sinister because the words `trade union' are in the amendment.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The minister has not been quite fulsome in her response in as much as things have been changed. Yes, this connection with newstart did exist under the previous government, but the minister has forgotten to remind the chamber that there have been many changes in the industrial relations law since then. There are very few areas which are considered to be legal industrial action any more, and more and more the industrial courts are restricted in enabling people to take industrial action. So things have changed. It is totally inappropriate to continue to put this kind of clause in any bill.
I would like to think the Labor Party will also consider that membership of a union in relation to youth allowance would not be the means by which people are discriminated and singled out, because so many things have changed. We all know how very few issues this government thinks can be acceptable for industrial action. During that debate we had issues like workers' health and safety which was so limited as to make workplaces dangerous. We know that people could not include meal breaks as allowable matters in their awards.
So many things have changed not only as a result of the federal legislation but also as a result of enabling state legislation that have made things even more restrictive. In Western Australia they are talking about fourth and fifth wave industrial legislation to make it harder and harder for people in the workplace to organise and for people to be engaged in anything that might in any way, shape or form be considered a legal strike or industrial action. The minister was not quite accurate when she said that this provision is the same as it has been before because the whole nature of industrial relations has changed since we dealt with this provision previously. I would 
 say that, at the very least, it is now totally inappropriate.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—The Democrats will support this amendment because of a number of concerns we have with the clause. I acknowledge the minister's comments in relation to similar provisions—as did Senator Dee Margetts—but I share the same concerns that Senator Margetts has just outlined. While there may be provisions similar to clause 553A that have already been enacted—and I think an example is section 596 of the Social Security Act—I am very concerned, as are my Democrat colleagues, that this sort of provision is inconsistent both with a number of existing laws and with our understanding of internationally recognised labour laws and labour rights.
The clear imputation of proposed section 553A is that if you are unemployed because you are involved in industrial action, then you bear the onus of proof of satisfying the department that you were not a member of the trade union. I am curious as to whether this is your reading too, Senator Margetts, but I believe this is inconsistent with the Workplace Relations Act which specifically protects the right to take industrial action in some circumstances. It is arguably inconsistent with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which says that everyone has the right to freedom of association with others and that that right should not be restricted. I think this provision, along with a number of others, is a particularly sinister provision and it is one we should reject in this bill. Therefore, we will be supporting the amendment before us.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —I have just sought to obtain a copy of the act. Would the minister detail whether or not the current provision that is proposed in clause 553A differs in any way from the provisions currently in the legislation for newstart allowance; and, if so, in what manner does it differ?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I have just been advised that there are some slight word 
 ing differences but that the effect is exactly the same. Perhaps I should also add that with the preclusion period changes to newstart a year ago—we are talking about the comparability of that legislation here—the government agreed to incorporate the Democrat amendments restricting the application of the preclusion period to the above circumstances only. Those circumstances are the ones I read out earlier that were inserted by the Democrats amendments with the acceptance of the government.
Nothing that we are doing here is different in effect from what happens now to newstart allowance. It is most undesirable, as Senator Bartlett has said a few times in this debate, that there be great variation between the way that various payments are administered. If you are going to worry, as I would, about mistakes being made by staff, about uncertainties and confusion as to people's entitlements or as to how they will be treated, then you do not try to vary these basic requirements if you can possibly help it. I cannot think of any justifiable reason why you would have different requirements for the newstart allowance from those for the youth allowance for the same activity.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The minister is somewhat inconsistent here. She is quite happy to treat young people differently when it comes to saving money for the government and has done so with this particular measure and series of measures. The minister cannot be serious about being consistent, because she is prepared to single out a group of people and say, `No, you can't get unemployment benefits and you can't get case studies if we decide that you are of the wrong age or wrong category.' When it is convenient, the minister is quite capable of singling out a group of people and disadvantaging them.
Minister, is it not young people who are less likely to be able to make agreements or negotiate by themselves? Are we not picking out young people and saying, `We don't want you to be part of a union; this is one of those cases where we are going to disadvantage young people for being part of a union'? I am very keen to find out what the Labor Party's 
 response to this is, considering that they, more than anyone else, should be aware of what kinds of changes have occurred between the time of the legislation that they were involved with and now, considering the change in the industrial climate in Australia. I ask whether the Labor Party is going to respond.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —Essentially, the waiting period requirement was introduced by the then Labor government. This bill seems to take bits and pieces out of the waiting period on a fairly ad hoc basis. It is really not going to assist people who are trying to access the benefits. Obviously, a great deal of uncertainty and confusion about the issue is of no particular assistance. The opposition thinks that retaining some certainty and clarity in the way the waiting period operates is the most important factor.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I find it extraordinary that we are singling out and penalising a group of people for being members of a union. We are talking about subclause 553A(2) of the bill. We are saying that unemployment due to industrial action means that a person has to wait longer to get any benefit. So we are not talking about the normal waiting period. That is why I want to know whether the Labor Party still thinks this is acceptable, considering the changes that have occurred in the industrial climate in Australia that mean there are so few areas considered by this government, under legislation, to be valid industrial action. Basically, this is not the normal waiting period; this is a penalty for people for being members of a union which has taken industrial action.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —As to that view which has been put by Senator Margetts, I would be grateful if the minister would clarify whether the waiting period for unemployed individuals who were involved in industrial action is consistent with that for those who are not working for a genuine reason.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The consistency is that the existing legislation for 
 newstart allowance has a preclusion period for people who are engaged in unlawful industrial disputes. I read out that, where there has been a breach of an order, direction or injunction issued by a state industrial authority, the Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court of Australia, the customer will be subject to an employment related preclusion period for youth allowance for a period of six weeks from the date the industrial action ceases. They are slightly different words, but I am advised that it has exactly the same effect as that for the newstart allowance, which was amended with some amendments from the Democrats to that effect last year. It was a continuation of giving industrial action special treatment in the previous legislation, but it has been ameliorated somewhat.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I am trying to discover whether someone who is involved in industrial action—
—Unlawful.
—unlawful industrial action has a longer waiting period than someone who is just unemployed.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —It is a bit difficult to answer because there are all sorts of waiting periods for different purposes depending on people's financial circumstances. Some waiting periods would be longer and some would be much shorter. It is about in the middle.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—To put some perspective on this, I remind the Senate that during the industrial relations debate the Greens (WA) pointed out that if, for instance, there was a dangerous situation at a workplace and those people in the workplace, other than the person who is specifically put in the dangerous situation, took industrial action in support of the person who is in that dangerous situation, under this government that would be considered unlawful industrial action.
There is a whole range of what I believe to be unfair circumstances which are now considered to be unlawful industrial actions. They could be trying to save the lives, or the future 
 lives and health, of your fellow workers. The government's industrial relations legislation says that only the person or persons being put in that position of danger can take lawful industrial action. They could be told to move on and put someone else in until someone is found who does not have the courage to stand up for themselves. Basically, we are talking about a whole range of issues which did not exist before—including trying to save the lives of your fellow workers.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —Minister, I was not completely clear on the answer you gave before. You said that the waiting period varies depending on the person's financial circumstances—which I accept—but in the case of two people who are in identical financial situations, in terms of their liquid assets and other things, and one person is unemployed because they have been dismissed and another person is unemployed because of what is called unlawful industrial action, is the waiting period different?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I am just double-checking with the minister. Subclause 4 talks about industrial action in breach of order, direction or injunction, but subclauses 1, 2 and 3 actually relate to  being engaged in industrial action, other people engaged in industrial action and length of employment related exclusion. Only clause 4 relates to unlawful industrial action. In fact, clauses 1, 2 and 3 relate to any kind of industrial action. If a person loses their job as a result of any kind of industrial action—that is the clause we are talking about, clause 2—then, Minister, you could be misleading the Senate if you are relating only to unlawful industrial action, couldn't you?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Mr Chairman, can I just help again here? If you are involved in industrial action which is not unlawful you obviously do not get unemployment benefits while you are engaged in industrial action but you go back onto payments as soon as that action ends. If you are engaged in industrial action which is unlawful on the basis of those specific decisions that I referred to earlier from the Industrial Relations Commission, the Federal Court, a state 
 industrial authority, et cetera, then you must wait six weeks. However, if you have any outstanding waiting periods which you are liable for—and maybe you were trying to ask me this, Senator—you serve them concurrently. You wait six weeks if you have been engaged in unlawful industrial action, but you serve that six weeks concurrently with anything else that you might be liable for.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—There is a situation here where a person is unemployed—not a person being on strike, we are talking about a person's unemployment. Those are the words of the bill. It relates to when a person's unemployment—that is, losing their job—is due to other people being, or having been, engaged in industrial action. So we have established now that we are not necessarily talking about illegal industrial action. We are in clause 4, but clauses 1, 2 and 3 are talking about any kind of industrial action.
We are talking about a person who has lost their job as a result, some way or another, of industrial action. In fact, what you are saying, but need to clarify, is that if a person has lost their job for one reason or another as a result of industrial action—lawful or unlawful—they will still be subject to this penalty clause.
—The question is—
—If the minister is going to answer that question, I would prefer it being in Hansard  rather than from the chair.
—It is not a matter of answering the question, Senator Margetts. I only call people who are standing and the minister was not standing. That is why I put the question.
—That is what I am suggesting would be reasonable. As the minister has made specific statements before, it is not unreasonable for her to put her response in Hansard  rather than from her seat.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Senator Margetts, I hesitated to get up and take the time of the Senate again because I just told you specifically: if somebody is engaged in 
 industrial action which is not deemed unlawful, they are eligible for unemployment payments as soon as the industrial action ends.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I will just refer the minister to page 65 of the bill under `Employment-related exclusions'. It states:
For the purpose of this Division, a person (other than a person who is undertaking full-time study) is subject to an employment-related exclusion while one or more of sections 553A to 553C apply to the person.
How can you say what you have just been saying?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—There is no inconsistency at all, Senator.
	 Question put:
	 That the requests for amendments (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move:
Schedule 1, item 6, page 97 (lines 21 to 23), omit subsection (4).
Schedule 1, item 6, page 99 (lines 22 to 24), omit subsection (3).
Amendments 17 and 18 are looking at unfair ways for the department to get away with not notifying a person properly when the penalties for breach can be very severe, including, if the government were to get its way, imprisonment. I really do think that it is not unreasonable to suggest that a person has the right to be notified if severe penalties apply.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —The opposition has moved a number of amendments relating to the methodologies for notification. That has been adopted by this chamber. Essentially, we will be opposing these amendments put forward by the Greens. Our approach is entirely different. It really would cause a completely contrary position to have this and our notification provisions.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I am grateful to the government for sending around some indication of what they will be doing, and why, in relation to these amendments. It will be good to have them on the record. The government's reply, as the minister has not jumped, is that the effect of this amendment would be to render unenforceable a notice to a customer merely because it failed to state that it was a recipient notice or how the customer was to comply with the notice.
The government are admitting in their response that they do not feel that it is necessary to say to the customer—that is, the insect wriggling around on the end of their pin—in this new privatised world that it was a recipient notice. So the person does not necessarily know what it is they have not complied with or how the customer—that is, the unemployed person—needs to comply. So it might be a bit difficult to blame a person for not complying 
 if the government is saying they do not need to tell a person what they need to do to comply.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I take no responsibility for what the government is stating in its response on paper. The amendments moved by the opposition—and already adopted by this chamber—clearly state that notification must be in writing and that it must state the consequences of failure to comply. We do have a fair and reasonable system of notification in place already. Whatever the government's position is with respect to these particular amendments, I do not think that affects that.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I would like to point out to Senator Neal that I was actually reading the government's own words. I am just saying that they say that the effect of this amendment would render unenforceable a notice to a customer merely because it failed to state that it was a recipient notice or how the customer was to comply with the notice.
The translation of that is that they believe it is acceptable to not notify a person that it is a recipient notice, so the person will not know necessarily whether they have had a recipient notice, or they are saying that it is okay to not tell the client—the unemployed person; let us call a spade a spade—how they are required to comply with the notice. They are the government's own words. There is nothing much I can do about the fact that that is the basis upon which the government is not agreeing to our amendments.
Amendments not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—I move:
(23)	 Schedule 1, item 6, page 98 (lines 16 to 23), omit the penalty and the note, substitute:
	 Penalty:	 30 penalty units.
(25)	 Schedule 1, item 6, page 100 (lines 10 to 17), omit the penalty and the note, substitute:
Penalty:	 30 penalty units.
I believe that Australian Democrat amendments 23 and 25 are the same as the Greens (WA) amendments. The purpose behind these 
 amendments is to remove the penalty that has been designated in the bill of six months imprisonment. We seek to replace the imprisonment as a penalty with a number of penalty units in relation to the refusal or failure to comply with notice.
I have a number of questions for the minister about this section. In particular, I am worried and curious about an understanding I have. Am I correct in my understanding that this particular penalty would apply not only to the young person in receipt of the youth allowance but also to the parent or the guardian if they are being paid the allowance? I will follow up some of those points, but a major concern, in relation to whether or not they notify the department, is that the penalty might apply not only to the young person but also possibly to the parent or the guardian of that young person who is receiving the youth allowance.
I know this has been canvassed many times in social security debates but I am wondering how many young people or people in receipt of benefits—there will always be a minority, presumably—will have some kind of event, whether it is major or minor, occur in their lives. Maybe it is not always the first thing that occurs to them that, yes, they must notify the department within a particular period. Of course it is within their legal rights to make that information known and to notify the department but, if they do not, are they criminals, and should they be subject to some kind of imprisonment? That is the fundamental objection that the Democrats have to this particular part of the bill. By all means, have a penalty—we have, on advice, put forward a penalty of 30 penalty units—but imprisonment? I look forward to hearing the minister's elaboration.
I have noticed while just looking over Senator Margetts's shoulder that there have been some arguments proffered by the government for a number of their objections on amendments. I have not actually seen that—I am not quite sure why. Perhaps that has gone to my office and I have not had an opportunity to read it. I do not really think that designating these young people, or in some cases their parent or guardian, as crimi 
 nals by enforcing up to six months imprisonment upon them is an appropriate punitive action. A penalty unit under the Crimes Act is the equivalent of, I understand, $110. It is probably worth noting that under Corporations Law I believe the penalty is $100, but it would not surprise me that there would be a differentiation in the way we treat people who are on benefits of some kind as opposed to people at the big end of town.
First of all, I ask the minister whether this penalty for failure to comply applies not only to young people in receipt of the allowance but to their guardians and parents as well.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —It applies to only the young person.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —In some ways perhaps we could call these kinds of amendments the former Senator Christabel Chamarette amendments because, as people would be aware, in debates on every social security bill former Senator Chamarette used to stand up and make it very clear that these kinds of imprisonment penalties were very inappropriate for so-called non-punitive bills. I keep reminding the minister of this, and that you are already dealing with many people who are struggling to survive. Of course, the deaths in custody reports consistently say that these kinds of penalties are inappropriate for what might in effect be breaches due to poverty. So I go along with the changes. They were in the Greens (WA) amendments as well, and we will be seeking support from this place for those.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —It would be appreciated if the minister could clarify that question about failure to comply with notices by parents. It seems to be logical to me that, if under this bill a person's eligibility for this payment is dependent upon their parents' income, at some stage the parents must be required to notify the Department of Social Security about their income. Is there no such requirement? If there is not, how does the department assess that young person's eligibility based on their parents' income?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Firstly, the 
 legislation in terms of the imprisonment penalty is the same as for all other social security legislation. There is nothing new or novel or strange about it; and it is rarely, if ever, used. Secondly, the requirement in all these cases of notification, et cetera, is imposed upon the young person and it is they who must satisfy the legislation or bear the penalty.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —That is exactly my concern. I think we have previously had the debate we are having on this bill—that is, all other social security payments have always been dependent on the income of the individual claiming the benefit. This is quite unusual and extraordinary in that it is dependent upon the income of someone else. It seems obvious to me that they are much more difficult circumstances and there must be some requirement to ensure that parents give advice as to what their income is.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —The requirement here is, as I said, on the young person. However, there are powers within the social security legislation where information is required, not specifically relevant to youth allowance, where other persons can be compelled to give information to the department about matters of income. In those cases, then the penalty would apply to the person required to provide the information. But that is not something that is new and novel to social security by virtue of the youth allowance; it is something which is already provided for in the act for any such requirement from the department.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I just want to clarify that point. If another person in a position of responsibility, such as a parent or a guardian, fails to comply, they face the penalty. So, if there were a situation where a parent fails to provide notification in relation to their son or daughter who is in receipt of the youth allowance, they are the ones who would attract that particular penalty—in this case, imprisonment.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The depart 
 ment does have means of collecting this information, as you would no doubt be aware. The situation is that, if that adult does not provide the information that is required, they are liable, as I am informed, to a harsher penalty than we are talking about here for the young person. But, once again, that is not specifically related just to youth allowance; that is a general provision in the existing legislation.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —Minister, you will have to clarify `harsher' penalty for me, because I am still at a loss to understand what is a harsher penalty than a term of imprisonment.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —While the minister is doing that, perhaps she could clarify what she meant by the word `adult'. Did she mean `parent' or `adult', because we might be dealing with the parent of an adult, but this government is treating them as a child?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I refer the Senate to section 1304, if they wish to look for the section that I am describing. I am told that the penalty is somewhat harsher in that it is up to 12 months imprisonment or a comparable non-imprisonment penalty.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I do not know whether your answer really clarified things for me. I will give you an example. It might make it clearer. A person who is not an adult under the definition of this act is means tested on their parents' income.
—Not financially independent.
—That is right. I assume they are required to notify if their parents' income increases to an extent which would affect their eligibility. If they fail to notify this, are they subject to this penalty?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —The answer, as I am advised, is that they would have to be in a position of knowingly not declaring a change in their parental income.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —So this is not a strict liability offence? You do have to show intent?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —People can be dealt with under the criminal law in this area, as you understand. So they would have to show intent, yes.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I have seen the memorandum that has been circulated by the minister to various senators. I acknowledge the departmental officers' rationale for not supporting the substitution of penalty units. Does the minister really believe that, if you do not refer to a term of imprisonment and you put `penalty units' instead, `this would make the situation less clear for customers as they would not know what the maximum penalty for an offence was without reference to the Crimes Act or some other secondary source'? Is it not sufficient to explicitly state a penalty that is not in a form of imprisonment? I cannot see how any less clear the penalty or punitive aspect could be if you stated `penalty units'; if you stated what a penalty unit equals—if you made it clear that 30 times, I believe, 110 is a big fat penalty. Is that really murky and unclear? Is it really necessary that there is a reference to imprisonment?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I simply emphasise again that that has long been a provision under the act—that breaches can be designated by the imprisonment terms that may come about by way of penalty. We believe our proposal is clearer to customers and it is consistent with other payments to leave that imprisonment penalty in the legislation. We certainly do not want to have the calculation of different penalties undertaken by 20,000 staff. You can imagine the difficulties that you would get with inconsistency and the concerns that Welfare Rights, for example, might have when people are not being treated consistently. It is very important in this area that there be certainty and consistency of treatment across payments. I think that is what we are doing with this and it is no more 
 onerous than any other provisions in this area in the act.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —How is an unemployed person a customer in this regard?

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I will not seek to answer that question; I will leave that for the minister. I will just go back to the question I asked the minister previously about whether there was any requirement of intent. The section that I understand is being altered by this amendment says:
A person must not, without reasonable excuse, intentionally or recklessly refuse or fail to comply . . . 
If someone is recklessly doing something, that does not, to me, seem to amount to someone intentionally not complying. It would seem to me to include a situation where a person was negligent. I have a concern that if someone negligently fails to do something they can be punished by imprisonment. I think that is a very different situation to someone who intentionally does not do something.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I am advised that the answer to the senator's question is that it is criminal recklessness and not civil recklessness.
Amendments not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I seek leave to move amendments 5 and 13 together, but I do have a further suggestion which I presume requires me seeking leave also. I would also like to seek leave not only to move Democrat amendments 6 and 7 on sheet 857 together but to actually deal with them first. I am happy to take the guidance of the chamber, but I think it makes more sense to deal with amendments 6 and 7 first before moving on to amendments 5 and 13. So I seek leave to move amendments 6 and 7 together, before amendments 5 and 13.
Leave granted.
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments: 

(6)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (line 15), omit paragraph (a).
(7)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 124 (lines 25 and 26), omit subsection (4), substitute:
Person aged 18 years or more
(4)	 A person is independent if the person is at least 18 years old.
These amendments relate to how we define independence for students as well as young unemployed people and, in one case, the independent criteria and age for those who are disadvantaged. I understand there are a number of similar amendments. Indeed, the amendments proposed by Senator Margetts on behalf of the Greens (WA) seek to achieve the same purpose—that is, to define the age of independence for a full-time student at 18, similarly with young unemployed.
We have had a number of speeches in this chamber during the second reading debate on some of these aged base criteria. The Democrats have put on record a number of times that we believe the government's concocted ages of independence are inconsistent, irrational and a sham. That is why we seek not only to get some degree of consistency in terms of the age at which young people and students are considered independent, but also to call on the opposition to commit to their previous record, which was reducing the age at which a student was considered independent from 25 to 22. So I look forward to hearing Senator Neal's comments in relation to the age of independence for a student as well as that for young unemployed.
I do acknowledge some of the debates that took place in this chamber last week, in particular the very compelling arguments from Senator Harradine. I note that he put on record his concern at the pressure that the proposed bill would put on Australian families, that perhaps lower and middle income earners would be hit harder because they would be expected to look after their children not only in an emotional sense but also in a financial sense until these children were young adults—up to 21 in cases to do with young unemployed and up to the age of 25 with respect to students. The Democrats have made clear our objections to that, but it was good to hear Senator Harradine's concern with not only the impact that that would have 
 on families—negative or otherwise—but also the stress and inconsistencies it would have on our taxation system.
On Thursday I learnt that perhaps some changes had been discussed between the government and the Independent senator. I am just wondering, given that I am moving these amendments now, what assurances or deals or otherwise the government has made with Senator Harradine that will alleviate the financial and other impacts of this legislation on families. Perhaps it is not appropriate for me and others to go ahead with our amendments because the changes that were debated last week between the government and Senator Harradine are so good for families and so good for young people that we do not need to alleviate some of the harshest aspects of this legislation.
First of all, I would like the minister to explain: what assurances has the government given Senator Harradine? What changes will be made—specifically, explicitly—to the taxation system to make sure that families do not feel the increased burden of this legislation? Perhaps that might convince us that we do not need to reduce the age of independence. Of course, we would not actually do that. We are dead keen to go ahead with the notion that we recognise in law and tax and otherwise that young people are adults at at least the age of 18 and that this legislation—the Commonwealth youth allowance legislation and other social security legislation—should reflect that fact.
In the same way that it benefits the government under other legislative frameworks—be it to do with child support and maintenance or whether it is to do with the family tax initiative—it suits the government to define young people as adults at 18, or at 16 in the case of the latter, so why not with the common youth allowance? Why is it that there is this huge gap between 18 in some cases and 25 under this legislation? Why is the government going ahead with this ridiculous notion that for a full-time student to meet the independent criteria they have to be 25 years of age?
I am looking forward to the government outlining how this will not impact harshly on 
 families and the specifics of the deal or otherwise that has been done with the Independent senator in this place that is designed, allegedly, to alleviate some of that burden and to change our taxation system. I am looking forward to being enlightened now as to how this legislation and its framework will be changing as a consequence of the government's deal last week.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I have some questions to add to that for the minister to look at at the same time. In addition to what Senator Stott Despoja was saying in relation to the proposed tax changes, how will it help a family which is already disadvantaged and not paying tax if they get a tax advantage, considering they may be paying little or no tax to start with? So, how could you, in a tax system, alleviate the disadvantages that these changes are bringing about?
The Greens (WA) amendment is identical to the one moved by the Democrats under Senator Stott Despoja so we will be supporting this. It reduces the age of independence to 18 for both students and unemployed. This makes sense. It makes sense for young people to be considered as independent while they are developing their independence, not after it. The current definitions of `dependent' and `independent' are confusing to understand. The minister has, just this very morning, spoken on the mantra of consistency. On a number of occasions the minister has said how we confuse social security offices if we are inconsistent. Here is the government's chance. In relation to the age of independence, there is no consistency at all between government departments let alone with the norms of society.
In their submission to the Price Report, the Sydney University Students Representative Council stated clearly the contradictions of the current system. They said:
The government continues to force citizens, who in every other respect (voting, health, insurance, licenses, alcohol etc) are seen as full citizens, to be relegated to the status of "dependent" if they happen to choose tertiary education. Our case work overwhelmingly shows that the majority of students are financially self-supporting from age 18 even if they live in the family home. 

Given that a person on attaining the age of 18 is considered to be an independent adult for the purposes of all other laws, it is illogical that students be considered financially dependent on their parents. For instance, you can put them into prisons with adults, can you not, Minister? It is illogical that students be considered financially dependent on their parents. The age of 18 is also the time that people become responsible for their own debts, including HECS debts and the Austudy supplement.
So the government and the ALP are saying that it is okay to create a debt to the government independent of your parents, but not acceptable to receive assistance from the government independent of your parents. This is double standards of the worse kind. We understand that the idea of reducing the age of independence to 18 may be a pretty radical idea to some in the chamber. It is the position of students and welfare groups, those having to deal with the consequences of government policy, not those who sit in their ivory towers and create policy.
But I do make an appeal to the ALP as the potential government to seriously consider supporting the call from young people and the young parties to support this entirely sensible and consistent amendment. Up until 1996 it was the ALP's stated position that the age of independence be set at 21—with many ALP politicians stating in education forums that 18 was the desired figure in the long term. However, the ALP's policy position seems to have been omitted from their amendments. While we strongly argue for the age of independence to be 18, we ask the ALP, at the very least, to stick to their policy in government; that is, for the age of independence to be 21 for now with a view to lowering it to 18 in a progressive fashion.
 We will get to those other amendments later. At that stage I will talk about various past inquiries and studies into the age of independence, with a view to gaining some understanding of contemporary opinion on the matter. So when we get to the next amendment I will go further into that. If members of the ALP are going to stand up in public fora amongst young people who count and who 
 vote from the age of 18, then put your money and your vote where you mouth is and support the Democrats and the Greens (WA) amendment to reduce the age of independence consistently to the age of 18.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—The effect of this amendment is to make the age of independence 18 for both students and unemployed. You might recall that the opposition argued quite strongly last week that those who were unemployed be treated as adults and given the same benefits as other adults even though they are between the ages of 18 and 20. But this amendment goes substantially further than that. It also brings down the age of independence for students to 18. That is a step we cannot take and the opposition will not be supporting this amendment.
There will be some further debate about the exact age of independence for students. There is a foreshadowed amendment relating to the issue of the age of independence on the table. It has been circulated already by Senator Carr. I assume that all parties have a copy of that. You may wish to obtain copies of that if you have not already. I assume that you are all very well aware of it.
There is some difficulty arguing that a person who is not seeking work but has made a decision to opt out of work to take up the advantages of higher education should receive an income from taxpayers. There is some concern in the community that the taxpayers, as well as paying for some substantial part of their education, should be paying them an income from the time they leave school. That is why we are having to weigh it up with demands in other areas like health and education and with demands from people in very dire circumstances. We find it very hard to justify saying that from the age of 18 students who are having the advantage of tertiary education should also be receiving that sort of benefit almost immediately.
As to the exact age of independence for students, during our time in government we were moving to a point where we saw the age of independence for students as being 21 and we were moving gradually over time to reach that point. We still believe that we should be 
 moving over time to that point but have some concerns about adopting that position immediately. Senator Carr will be discussing that issue more when he moves the opposition amendment in that area. It is sufficient to say at this stage that we will not be going as far as this amendment and the opposition will be opposing it.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I was presuming that the minister would like to speak next, but I thought I would clarify some of my more general questions earlier. I am just wondering if the minister envisages changes to the family tax initiative as a result of the discussions that took place last week. Will that be changed as part of the attempt to alleviate some of the financial hardship on families? Perhaps that would be one aspect of the assurances or otherwise that were given to Senator Harradine last week. I would like to get a sense of what changes are being envisaged.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I apologise to the committee for being absent for 20 minutes or so. I understand there has been a question raised in the debate concerning discussions I had had with the government subsequent to a previous occasion that I stood on my feet. I am happy to reiterate what I deliberately asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the last occasion I had a question—I was going to say `without notice', but I will say deliberately that I had a question to direct to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
That question was deliberately asked of the Leader of the Government as representing the Prime Minister in this place. In effect, the essence of the question was, should not essential income transfers within a family be also recognised within the taxation system, and is it the intention of the government to include in its restructuring of the Australian taxation system a measure to give further recognition to the functions of parents in raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers?
That question was quite deliberately asked on the basis that we had been given quite definite statements by the Minister for Social 
 Security on behalf of the government, and indeed by other ministers in the government, publicly earlier last week that, if there were substantial amendments made by the Senate to this legislation, those amendments would obviously need to go down to the House of Representatives. The government had no intention of supporting those amendments in the House of Representatives. Under those circumstances, they would send the bill back to the Senate and, if we insisted, the bill would in effect go into limbo.
Under those circumstances I think we in the chamber needed to consider those matters, and the question was, when did we need to consider them? You might argue that it could have been a good idea to send the bill back there and give a bit of a chance to deal with the matter. But the problem is that, had we done that, we would have disadvantaged some 27.5 or 28 per cent of current youth allowance recipients who stood to gain from the legislation.
As I understand it, 64 per cent of youth allowance recipients would not in fact have their youth allowance changed, six per cent would incur some sort of reduction in their youth allowance and two per cent would lose the youth allowance altogether. The other 0.5 per cent would not be eligible because they would take a deliberate decision not to be involved with this measure. Under those circumstances, I did deliberately ask that question of the minister, having, as some of you may have seen, spoken to the Prime Minister. The government leader stated quite categorically:
I can, therefore, assure Senator Harradine that in restructuring the Australian taxation system, to which this government is committed, the government will give further recognition and help to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities in . . . raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers.
I am aware, and others will be aware, that there are some in government who may not wish to see that situation, but the Prime Minister is committed to it and he committed his government, not just himself, not to consider further recognition but in fact to give further recognition and help, to use his words, 
 to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities.
—No guarantee.
—Senator Stott-Despoja, I would love an opportunity later this afternoon or some other time to go into the question of the importance of the family, even from a human rights perspective. I am happy to do that and I am happy to put my record against your party's record over a number of years on this particular matter. Please, let us continue it at some later time.
Progress reported.

name: Allison, Sen Lyn
text: —Pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask Minister Herron, representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, for an explanation as to why an answer has not been provided to my question on notice, No. 1067, which was asked on 9 February.

name: Herron, Sen John
text:
—I suspect it is because my departmental liaison officer is off on paternity leave. But I will check that out and get an answer to the question as soon as possible.
—It's a good try.
—It is true, Senator Schacht. I am sure there is an answer to that question, Senator Allison. I will get it to you as soon as possible either today or tomorrow.

name: Allison, Sen Lyn
text:
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the failure of the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Herron) to provide either an answer or an explanation.
I point out that, as I say, this question has been—
—Order! There are too many conversations and too much movement in the chamber.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Is it competent for Senator Allison to move such a motion without leave at this point?
—I did not hear what she was moving. That was why I was asking for some silence.
—I will proceed with this point of order if it is required.
—Senator Allison, I did not hear what you were saying just before Senator Faulkner rose.
—I moved a motion that the Senate take note of the minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation. As I understand it, that does not require leave.
—Under standing order 74, that may be moved without leave.
—I remind the minister that not only has this question been outstanding for more than 30 days but also I have raised this matter on two other occasions in the past week—a notice of motion on Thursday last week and an adjournment speech, both of which referred to this matter of the exemption for the Australian Grand Prix from the tobacco advertising ban. I think it is very disappointing that the minister has not answered my question, especially since the grand prix has now come and gone. Any opportunity to take advantage of the minister's answer has now been lost by that event. I point out that the minister has had plenty of notice that this was coming up. Again, I am most disappointed that the minister has not been able to answer the question.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Abetz, Sen Eric
text:
—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
That the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 12 March 1998, from 9.30 am to 10.30 am and from 4 pm to 7.30 pm, to take evidence from the Australian Consumers Association, the Australian Customs Service and the Department of Communications and the Arts, as part of the committee's inquiry into the Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997.

name: Carr, Sen Kim
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the Senate take note of the document. 

The Auditor-General's Report No. 35 of 1997-98—Performance audit—DEETYA International Services: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs  highlights yet again another difficulty with that department. While the concept of promoting and expanding export opportunities in the field of education and training is one that I fully support and encourage, I do think that this is, yet again, an opportunity to highlight some difficulties that are emerging with the administration of this portfolio.
It is unfortunate that the problems that the Auditor-General has identified with this particular division are now becoming indicative of a broader problem within DEETYA. What the Auditor has established is that this particular section was not operating successfully in a range of areas which included financial planning, management of risks and cost methodology. As a result of its shortcomings in the way in which this program was administered there seems to be an accumulated cash deficit of $1.4 million.
While that may not be a particularly large sum of money in the context of this department it is nonetheless worthy of note. I want to emphasise that I actually support the expansion and promotion of Australian export opportunities in education. What I do not support, however, is the problems that are now emerging within DEETYA as a direct result of the decline in the resourcing and staffing of this department. It seems to me that the levels of staffing within this department are now such that issues surrounding overall accountability, management and monitoring of programs raise serious concerns within this parliament at large.
DEETYA is not alone when it comes to the problems surrounding these particular matters. This has been highlighted by DEETYA and senior officials of DEETYA itself before the estimates committee last Friday. What has been highlighted there is the inability to keep an accurate track of the spiralling increase in the use of consultancies. In my view, Dr Kemp has to take direct and personal responsibility for this because he has attempted to cover up the extent to which this department has become dependent upon consultants. We 
 have seen the way in which its agencies as well as the department have now used consultants in a very limited period. A small window has opened to us, through which we have been able to establish that some $7 million has been spent on consultants.
We have seen that this department has been gutted by this government. It has lost 80 per cent of its staff. This was the second biggest spending department in government. Its staffing figures, as revealed before the estimates by the secretary to the department, highlight that it has moved from 16,000 people two years ago down to some 2,500 people over the next financial year. This department has been gutted. The situation has now arisen where this government is seeking to spend millions and millions of dollars in consultancies to cover up the failure of this particular portfolio.
What we have here is a government engaged in a callous exercise of job replacement. Thousands of public servants are being shown the door and they are being replaced by consultants at an ever increasing rate of expense to undertake the work that was once done by officers of the department.
The secretary to the department has admitted some embarrassment with regard to the way in which the department itself is not able to maintain its record systems properly any more. He has been able to identify to us that three separate lists of consultants were provided to the estimates committee as a result of questions that I have raised.
The fact remains that the department still has not got it right. For this limited period of time during which we were seeking information, they were not able to distinguish between a consultant and a service provider on a consistent basis. This government has shown that its attempt to use the idea of a service provider has meant some $1 million of the $7 million can be reallocated away from the publicly declared requirements under the annual reporting provisions that are a normal part of public administration into an area which does not require public accountability at the same levels.
What we have seen is an attempt to hide the massive blow-out in consultancies by this 
 government and by this minister, who is engaged in a consultancy binge in an attempt to secure the advice that he wants—not independent, impartial, analytical advice from a fearless, independent public service but advice that he can control in a manner which is not subject to the normal rigours of the parliamentary system. In so doing, he increasingly provides that advice to consultants or service providers depending on what day of the week it is and depending on which officer actually engages the contract. Sometimes it can only be one officer. Only one officer is now required to make up a selection panel for some of these very expensive consultancies in a manner that means that the advice can be tailored to meet the demands of government rather than provide the independent basis of advice that we normally come to expect from the Public Service.
The fact that we have had a reduction in staffing in this department—the privatisation of this department by stealth from 16,000 people two years ago to 2,500 people in the space of two years—is deplorable. The fact that we have had to expose it through the estimates process is the bombshell that Senator Tierney is so anxious to avoid. It is the bombshell that they are so concerned about.
We have a climate of staff reductions, a department that is hideously embarrassed by the way in which these policies have been administered and a minister who shows no embarrassment, because he is shameless. We have a government that is shameless as to the consequences of its policies which will have a detrimental effect on the students and the unemployed of this country. We have an acknowledgment by the department of the inconsistent application of guidelines with regard to the use of consultants and service providers. We have clear evidence that the department's records are in a  complete shambles, despite the secretary's guidelines and despite the Public Service guidelines in terms of a procurement of government services.
What we have is the capacity now for individual officers to have the discretion to determine what consultancies should go forward and what should not. What we have 
 therefore is a government that has been working in a climate where DEETYA is not able to fulfil its obligations. There is little wonder that there have been so many scandals within this department? Is there little wonder that there have now been two ministers embroiled in the crises within this department?
—And how many secretaries?
—There have been three secretaries in this department. I thank Senator Mackay very much for that interjection. There have been three secretaries in the space of three years because of the scandals within this department, which is not the responsibilities of individual officers. It is because they have to carry the burden of government policy, which is totally inappropriate to the needs of this country. We have seen staffing reductions of 80 per cent. We have a budget demand by this government that, despite the fact that this department has 10 per cent of total government expenditure, it is required to carry 30 per cent—$4.3 billion—of the budget cuts.
Of course there will be problems and of course there will be crises as a result of the actions of this government. They have completely wiped out the corporate memory of this department. Is there any wonder that one problem after another is emerging as a result of the actions of this government which have reduced this department to a shadow of its former self.
It concerns me greatly that members opposite in this chamber express so little concern about the loss of service to the students and the unemployed of this country, so little concern about the consequences of a failure of government policy, so little concern about the loss of public moneys, so little concern about the questions of probity that are now emerging with regard to the employment market services and so little concern about the appalling failure in process that has resulted from 75 per cent of ANTA's consultancies going out in one period without a full and open tender process.
An increasingly small number of consultants are getting the benefit of an increasingly larger sum of money as a result of fewer and 
 fewer officers being made available to carry out the functions of this department. Is there little wonder that people ask why it is that everyone else in this country is required to operate on an open and competitive basis, as this government says, but the government operates on such a narrow, restricted basis—on the basis of selective invited tenders.

name: Tierney, Sen John
text:
—The government welcomes Auditor-General's Report No. 35 of 1997-98—Performance audit—DEETYA International Services: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs —a very valuable report which confirms a number of management reforms that have been introduced recently by DEETYA International Services. One of the major reforms has been the adoption of a new DIS operational framework based on a cost recovery model which addresses the areas which ANAO has highlighted needs improvement. These include financial planning, management of risk and costing methodology.
Following the adoption of this framework, DIS has revised its business plan to focus on continuing improvement links of output based budgeting and reporting, it is developing a comprehensive risk management plan and it is moving to full accrual based financial management. These reforms will further contribute to DIS's success in winning tenders and obtaining client satisfaction for services which are delivered.
The ANAO report on DIS acknowledged the vital contribution that DIS is making to export opportunities for Australian education, training and labour market providers in a number of regions, including the countries of South-East Asia, central Asia and eastern Europe. Over the last four years DIS has secured contracts worth $9.6 million in these very important export markets. The current financial difficulty in some countries in our region coupled with increasing competition and the imperative of Australian groups targeting markets carefully has been included so that DIS will work harder to improve the position to respond to current and future demands in the marketplace.
It was interesting that Senator Carr spent only a few minutes concentrating on the findings of the report and also the way in which the government has moved very quickly—even before the report was brought down—to institute a number of changes. It has established a relatively new organisation. It has been established in a Public Service culture, and it has to have a market orientation. Of course, this combination in the early stages does create some difficulties. It has recognised those difficulties and it is moving very quickly to reform this body.
Senator Carr's broader remarks relating to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs show a lack of knowledge of the history of DEETYA. He seems to indicate that the problems have come from the current change in arrangements. He obviously has no knowledge of the history of the sorts of things that were happening six or seven years ago—in 1991, when the Auditor-General did heavily qualify his report into DEETYA under Senator Carr's government eight years after they came into government. As a matter of fact, things were in such a shambles at that time that in the following year DEETYA appointed 40 internal auditors to try to fix up the mess in the accountability systems. Over the years since then, DEETYA has, to its great credit, got its act together and improved accountability arrangements. Over seven years I certainly have not seen any backsliding from that.
Senator Carr went on to talk about various things relating to consultancies and outsourcing. If we restructure the way in which we provide these services, which this government has done, and if we move to a more market based approach, obviously we do not need as many public servants. The test in the end will be the way in which services are delivered and the way in which people do end up being placed in real jobs. I would have thought that sort of outcome is the ultimate test that we should be looking at.
Look at the appalling record of Senator Carr's government in relation to not only the high levels of unemployment that developed during the time Labor were mismanaging this country but also the way in which they then 
 approached the problem. Sure, they employed an enormous number of public servants and committed billions of dollars to the exercise. I suppose in a way that is commendable—except that they did not get the outcomes, which meant they got the worst of both worlds: they wasted taxpayers' dollars and people were still in the unemployment queue. They had a totally hopeless approach to this.
In 1996 the voters in this country thoroughly recognised the hopelessness of Labor's approach in their `not Working Nation' scheme and threw them out of office. Voters wanted a totally different approach. This government has brought in this approach, and there is every sign that it will have a much better chance of success than the mess those opposite created in the unemployment area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Ferris, Sen Jeannie
text:
