—On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a report of the committee on the examination of the annual report for 1996-97 of the National Crime Authority. I seek leave to move a motion and make a short statement in relation to the report.
Leave granted.
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the report.
The committee carefully examined the annual report of the National Crime Authority. We were pleased to see that the NCA has taken into account the changes that were requested of the authority in the presentation of its information last year in its annual report. We were reassured by the greater clarity of analysis of the information in the annual report—particularly the statistical information—compared with that in the past. It is very clear that the NCA is engaged in a quiet but very effective war against drugs.
I would like the Senate to take note of the fact that over the past three months the NCA has made a number of significant arrests in 
 connection with the drugs war. There were five networks involving the use of heroin that were smashed, with 17 people arrested, including a number of senior crime figures. There were three arrests and the seizure of 21 kilos of heroin with a street value of $32 million. There were nine arrests and an interstate heroin ring broken. Twelve people were arrested in three raids with heroin, cocaine, firearms and stolen goods seized. In another case there were 10 individuals arrested and a syndicate was cracked that operated in Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia. While the war against these drugs is of course ever-present and far from won, it is clear that the NCA is making significant inroads into this very sad human tragedy in Australia.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—I would like to make some brief remarks about the report by the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on the examination of the annual report for 1996-97. The annual report has been examined by the committee and found to be satisfactory for a number of reasons—its improved presentation, its timeliness and its relationship to the corporate plan. These are indeed mostly housekeeping issues. But, more importantly for the Australian Democrats, we are concerned that where a person's name is included in a report in the context of them being charged, it is essential that, if the matter does not proceed or if the person is found not guilty, the matter be included in the annual report. The report states at paragraph 27:
The Committee acknowledges the fine line between `suspected' and `charged' prior to the matter going to court and sympathises with the NCA, as a law enforcement body, not wishing to breach its own enabling legislation.
I can only say that the reporting of not guilty and charges withdrawn matters are absolutely essential. This approach should be reconsidered in the near future to ensure the practice does not place undue hardship on those charged and later found to be not guilty or to have the charges dropped.
I also, for the record, would like to restate my concerns about the investigation into the 
 bombing of the NCA office in Adelaide. As we all know in this chamber, this was one of the most serious attacks on a law enforcement agency in this nation's history. It occurred in my home state of South Australia on 2 March 1994. That bombing killed Geoffrey Bowen and maimed Peter Wallis. Despite the fact that this happened more than three years ago, there has been no successful prosecution of this crime. Of course, there are many questions that remain unanswered; there are many outstanding questions. This is not good enough from the perspective of our law enforcement agencies. I believe that it is the role of this parliament, and our responsibility, to make sure that we get to the bottom of this particular tragic event.
I understand that security has been beefed up on NCA recommendations. I understand, for example, that all mail is now X-rayed and other measures are in place to protect from harm these agencies and the individuals that work within them. If this is not the case, however, if there are any loopholes whatsoever, something must be done to bring the protective measures up to standard. I note that the Democrats have raised these concerns in this place on a number of occasions. We believe that those people who are in a position of authority and who are charged with the responsibility of protecting others are entitled to the maximum level of physical and other security available. The lives of those in public service are indeed valuable, like all other lives, and we must learn the lessons of this particular tragedy to make sure that nothing like it at all happens again.
I am also concerned about the coroner's inquest. After three years the South Australian coroner's office has not convened an inquest into this tragedy because the police investigation has not been finalised. I understand that is the rationale and that this is standard practice in my home state. However, given the lack of prosecution after all this time—it is over three years, as I said—we should be seeking answers as to why the coroner's inquest has not even started. I believe this investigation is central to resolving this tragedy and learning the lessons so that this never happens again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I indicate to the Senate that those bills which have just been announced are being introduced together. After debate on the motion for the second readings has been adjourned, I will be moving a motion to have three of the bills listed separately on the Notice Paper . I move:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I will not reiterate the nature of the amendments, which relate to the various exemptions for the youth allowance for people who are disadvantaged and the reduction in the age of independence. But I reiterate the questions I asked the minister earlier in this committee stage as to what measures her government was going to intro 
 duce in order to meet the concerns that Senator Harradine raised last week, specifically in relation to changes to taxation arrangements and the taxation burden on families in this country. I am still very curious to note what has been discussed between the government and Senator Harradine and how families will find their financial and other burdens alleviated as a result of the assurance that Senator Harradine has been given. If he has not been given any specific assurances or specific deals or taxation changes then I would like to know about it. I am very concerned to know what has been organised between those two parties.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I am also very concerned that if some arrangement has been reached between the government and Senator Harradine that the government disclose what that arrangement is. Obviously it is something that bears on Senator Harradine's mind sufficiently enough that he felt fit not to continue with the very firm views he originally expressed in the chamber—on Wednesday evening I think it was. There seems to be a difficulty with democratic processes if two parties involved in the Senate, the government and one Independent member, can secretly exchange information that affects the law-making of this chamber. If there are details that affect the outcome of this bill they should be disclosed by the government immediately. More and more it seems that the government is making secret arrangements with particular members of the Senate in order to prevent open debate on issues that should be public.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I find it curious that the opposition is unable to accept the explanation that was given by Senator Harradine today. It is for Senator Harradine to talk to the Senate about any matters that he has discussed with the Prime Minister. It is not for me to discuss that.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—Minister, you are a member of the government; you represent the government here today. You have a responsibility to disclose to all members of the Senate any issues that are pertinent to this debate. I 
 suppose it is up to Senator Harradine to disclose whether he has had personal discussions with the Prime Minister but I am concerned about what government policy changes are being made that will have an impact on this particular bill.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I made it perfectly clear last Thursday that this government has already evidenced its concern for families with dependent children. Virtually the first thing it did when it came into government was to honour its election commitment of a $1 billion family tax initiative to relieve families of some of the costs and burdens of raising children. Senator Harradine did believe, I understand, that that was a very valuable initiative. I do not think that there is any point in belabouring that issue. I would have thought that the opposition would have seen that that was a valuable example of the government's commitment to families with dependent children.
I also said last Thursday that the government's management of the national accounts has been such that we have had five reductions in interest rates since we came into government. This has meant that families have had, effectively, something like a $90 to $100 a week pay rise because of the reduction in the burden that they have had in meeting their family mortgages.
We have not been running around with rhetoric on those things but taking no action, like the previous government did. We have actually put those things into place which have benefited and helped families who are raising children. The Prime Minister and Senator Harradine may have had their conversation—and I am not able to help you on that—but I know that the Prime Minister has made it absolutely clear that tax reform is on agenda for this government and that we will go to the next election with people well and truly understanding what proposals are available for them to pass judgment on. It will be absolutely clear that one of the principles on which that tax reform is based is that we recognise appropriately the special demands placed on parents by the raising of children 
 and the need for that to be recognised in the tax system.
We have already moved to that partially with the family tax initiative when we first came into government. We have also talked about the need for compensation, where appropriate, for any change to the tax structure. I imagine—and that is for Senator Harradine to discuss if he wishes—that Senator Harradine has found that the assurances the Prime Minister has given him are satisfactory because, and here is the crunch, Senator Neal, this legislation will be beneficial for very many young people and their families.
—What about others?
—You might carp about things that you do not think are as good as they might be—because you have the luxury of that from opposition—but you were not prepared to move to do this when you were in government despite the fact that the welfare organisations were asking for you to move in this direction.
—They were not asking for us to move in that direction!
—They have told me that they were asking. They were very happy to be involved in consultations and make submissions as to how the youth allowance should be implemented. Do not be under any misapprehension that this important social policy reform was badly needed to send the right messages to young people that it is better to be acquiring skills than to be jumping out of school too early and remaining unemployed for a very long period and perhaps becoming unemployable over time. It is very important to send the right message to young people that we do not believe it is desirable that young unemployed people are getting paid more money than those would who are studying to improve themselves and their country.
There are a number of very important messages to young people in this legislation. Senator Harradine has clearly had the opportunity to study the bill thoroughly and believes that to stand in the way of a very important piece of social policy would be 
 wrong, given that he has been assured by the Prime Minister that this government is determined to tackle tax reform in a meaningful way so that it is advantageous to families with dependent children.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I could not let that pass without reminding the Senate that what we did get from the government in relation to family tax was a marginal tax system which was highly complex and extremely intricate. The reason it was set up that way was to try to make it look as if the gain was $1,000 when it was a lot less. The reality is that the government said they were giving $1,000 and in fact what people got in their pockets was a lot less. It was extremely complex; it is probably extremely expensive to administer as well. It was a con basically because it gave a lot less than what it promised—and it did not help much at all people who did not pay tax.
If the government are suggesting that they did such a good job with their family tax last time—their marginal tax effort—that they are going to do the same kind of thing again, we are on to them. It was a con last time. It was a scam to look as if the government were giving more than they did. As I recall, Senator Harradine at the time was very critical of the way the government put that together. So I certainly hope you are not going to came with the same kind of thing and add a figure on and pretend you are giving another $1,000 to Australian families because we are on to you. We have seen what you did before.
The important message that the minister is suggesting is perhaps one she took from Malthus, from a previous century, that you have to be cruel to be kind; that if you give the poor money they will only have babies. That kind of message is the kind of outdated, old-fashioned, inappropriate and cruel message that is coming from the government. The kinds of questions that we have been asking have not been answered by the government. What did happen about the explanatory memorandum the first time that suddenly meant we had an extra $100 million? When did we get the answer to that? Where are the figures from the government as to how the figures got changed by $100 million between 
 when the questions were asked and when the minister answered them and when the explanatory memorandum was published?
We are told that we should accept what the government is saying that people are going to be better off. We have had no figures at all to show that. The amendments we are asking for support for here are about the real impact on real people. The Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats believe that it is not just a matter of definition on paper; it is a matter of whether families will be able to survive. We do not believe that it is acceptable to say, `Oh well, if you have got kids who are in school or in training'—magically, considering the amount of money not available for schools and training from this government—`you might be better off if they are in those things.' If you look at the longer term picture that is not quite true. If you look at the impact on people who are unemployed for a longer period of time the picture gets worse.
None of those questions have actually been answered. Yet we are still being asked to accept that it is all right to discriminate against young people and to pick and choose what the age of independence is depending on whether or not the government feels it can save money; and that it is all right to call a person independent if there is a chance of getting money out of them—like their accepting debts and so on. But it is not okay to accept the age of independence as 18 unless you accept the responsibility that if those young people, like any other adult person in our society, are unemployed or need assistance with training or education they are entitled to receive it.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—The name Malthus has got me to my feet. For the past 22 years I have been pointing out the nonsense of neo-Malthusians—amongst whom you can class yourselves, perhaps—in and out of this chamber. And now what have we got? On the population bomb we have a recent discussion at the UN expressing concern about the demographic disasters that are going to beset the world because of the ageing population, and there has been this campaign, supported by a number of people whom I will not mention 
 who are in this chamber, that there should be restrictions placed upon parents as to the number of children—indeed bordering on support for the Chinese one child per family policy. Over the years I have been pointing this out, and I have been proven right over all of those years, and now I hear the name Malthus in this particular debate.
—He was an economist—of sorts!
—Yes, a pretty crook economist. I often quoted the very good work of Julian Simon—who recently passed away—and I pay tribute to his work over the many years when it was not fashionable to tell the truth and to warn of demographic disasters. And that is what we are threatened with at the present moment.
Senator Neal has asked a question—and I think I owe it to her, the opposition and others to respond—but I would like to remind honourable senators that on 5 March the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), made a deliberate commitment, and I repeat it:
I can, therefore, assure Senator Harradine that, in restructuring the Australian taxation system . . . the government will give further recognition and help to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities in  . . . raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers.
That undertaking was given in the context of the proposed restructuring of the taxation system. It was not a short-term thing as to what is going to happen in the next budget; I am not privy to what is going to happen in the next budget, on this or any other matter. I was more interested in the long-term outcomes for families as a result of the taxation restructuring situation.
As we all know, there is a government task force, chaired by Senator Brian Gibson, which is examining a large number of submissions. What the Prime Minister did, and this was confirmed publicly here in the chamber, was to give me that assurance in the context of the restructure. If the government ultimately goes to some sort of consumption tax—which I have considered over the years to be, either in fact or potentially, regressive—you then 
 have a look at what the Prime Minister has committed the government to. He has committed it to giving further recognition and help; not that they will give consideration to it, but they will, so that the outcome will have to be better for families than it is now, even under a consumption tax. That is a very important and significant undertaking, and I will not take it lightly.
Honourable senators will realise that over many years, both in the trade union movement and on the ACTU, I was involved in discussions, and Albert Monk actually came out as a very strong supporter of family payments and family allowances. I think it was at an ACTU congress in the early 1960s when we went through it and he came out as a strong supporter of family allowances supporting children. He was in opposition to some of those people who were on the population control bandwagon—the population bomb bandwagon—and I pay full credit to Albert Monk for what he did in those days against the sort of pressure that was being brought to bear on him and on the rest of us in the ACTU executive.
 No doubt Senator Neal will be as keen as I am to make sure that the Prime Minister delivers on his undertaking which was publicly stated here in the chamber by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. I can assure Senator Neal that I will be as keen as she is, and the opposition no doubt will be, I hope, to see, as the Prime Minister has said, in effect, that families with children will be better off under the outcome of the taxation restructuring. If we can hold him to that, I think we will have achieved a good deal. I do not for one moment consider that the Prime Minister would renege on such an assurance, because I believe that he is very firmly committed to it himself. I have come to that conclusion from the way he has spoken on this particular matter.
So there it is. I had to ask myself this question: what could be achieved through this? Here we were in the Senate, as I said before, faced with the proposition that if we amended this legislation substantially it would have no hope. It would go back to the House of Representatives, the government would 
 defeat our amendments, it would come back up to the Senate and, if we insisted, the whole thing would be shelved—and with what result?
As I said before lunch—and I am not saying anything different this time after lunch; I have been there and done that on the RDA—there were winners in this. I have figures from the Parliamentary Library with regard to winners and losers. The government figures were that 27½ per cent of current youth allowance, or equivalent, recipients would be better off; 64 per cent would remain the same; six per cent would experience a reduction; and two per cent would lose the allowance, whatever allowance they were on.
That is not a satisfactory situation, I agree. But one has to look at it squarely and think, well, what is the best outcome that can be achieved? Rightly or wrongly, I decided that it was time to respond to a request for a meeting. That took place, and the outcome you know.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—Senator Harradine, I do not doubt your desire to bring about a positive result for those families who might be affected adversely by this bill. But I suppose what worries me a little are the broad terms in which the undertaking was given by Senator Hill.
—Not only over this bill; it was a general undertaking for families.
—It says:
. . . further recognition . . . help to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities . . . raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers.
The difficulty, of course, is that that undertaking does not specifically say that people who are affected adversely by this particular aspect of the bill being debated at the moment will be compensated.
What there was particular concern about, which I think we discovered in the debate last week, was that the parents of adult children—and I say `adult children' because those between 18 and 20 are adults—were going to lose $135 million. On the face of it, it seems to me that this undertaking by Senator Hill does not give any sort of guarantee that that particular group of families who lose that 
 $135 million will be compensated in any way in this future tax restructuring, if the present government has the opportunity to bring that restructuring about.
Within the tax system, on nearly any interpretation that I have ever been aware of—and I am happy for people to correct me if they believe there is an example—`family' has been defined as `having children of less than 18 years'. So how can any proposal within the tax system compensate families with adult children between the ages of 18 and 20? If it is the intention of this government to make payments to families in that particular position, it is obviously a very relevant consideration and a matter that I believe the government should disclose openly.
The debates held within the Senate, I believe, should be carried out on a transparent basis. All decision makers involved, all senators, should have access to information which will affect their ultimate position on the bill. If the government says, `We have information that may affect your decision making on this issue but we are just not going to give it to you,' I think the government is treating the Senate and many senators with a lack of respect, and I do not think that is a very good precedent for this government to start with.
Certainly I would very much like to know as an individual senator—and I am sure that all opposition senators would like to know—whether the government is proposing to make changes to compensate this particular group of people. If the government is proposing to do so, it will obviously impact on our position, and we would very much like to be aware of it.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—In terms of the amendments before the chamber at the moment which, as I understand it, relate to the relevant age level of independents, I would back up the request that Senator Neal has made as to detail and whether or not any more is available. Regardless of whether or not the Democrats support this aspect of the legislation, from my perspective, that certainly helps when going back out into the community and explaining to 
 people the rationale behind decisions that have been made.
I would very much appreciate more information, if there is any, from either the Minister for Social Security or perhaps Senator Harradine in relation to this tax reform and the further recognition and help that will be given to parents in raising their sons and daughters—whether those sons and daughters include those above the age of 18, and whether there will be any help in this tax reform specifically for parents' sons and daughters in that age group.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—As I said, it is not for me to say and I do not know, nor did I ask, in respect of the budget. This legislation is coming in from 1 July, as I understand it. What the government does in the budget might be one thing, but let us get it very clear that we have been told by the government that we will ultimately have a completely restructured taxation system, introduced sometime in the new financial year. I assume that that is going to be put to the people. I do hope it is going to be put to the people in the election campaign. That, I understand, is the intention of the government. So it will be open and transparent.
I was looking to an ongoing beneficial outcome to families, and I specifically mentioned parents concerning their responsibilities in raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers. I pointed out the need to recognise, in whatever taxation system that emerges, the intra-family transfers that take place. If they are going to assume that those are taking place and test the youth allowance on that particular assumption, it is only fair that the government should recognise that transfer for the purposes of minimising the tax of those parents and also helping those other parents who may, even though they are on a relatively high income, have an income tax neutral situation.
I agree with what Senator Margetts implied, that you have got to be paying tax to have something recognised in the tax system. That is one of the reasons that the word `help' is there. I do not think there is anything more that I can enlighten you on, other than to say that I look forward to assistance to ensure that 
 this undertaking is honoured, which I have no doubt it will be.
As to Senator Neal's reference to the specific parents involved in income testing, which will affect some six per cent, or eight per cent counting the other two per cent, of the youth allowance recipients, they will be covered by what was said, but it is not limited to those persons. It is an undertaking that the government will give further recognition and help to Australian parents in that particular work that is their priority, that is, the raising and education of their sons and daughters.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—First of all, I point out that Senator Neal's contribution has to be the height of hypocrisy. Her government was perfectly prepared to parentally means test the families of students, many of whom are exactly the same families of the young unemployed. You had no problem in parentally means esting them. Not only that, Senator Neal, you were not prepared to lift a finger to give them any family tax relief. It was not until this government came in that any family tax relief was applied at all.
Senator Margetts is prepared to dismiss the family tax initiative as not being very important. She may have a very short memory. I point out to her that the welfare organisations of Australia came out very enthusiastically—
—Until they saw how it was restructured.
—They were saying how well the family tax initiative was targeted to low and middle income families, and that something like 50 per cent—
—Is that the first day—before they saw how you did it? That was before they saw how you did it.
—You will have your turn, Senator, when you get the call. Just now, you listen to me. Something like 50 per cent of the families were on low to middle incomes. Some of them were not in fact paying tax and therefore they received their assistance through the social security system. I would have thought you might have pondered on that somewhat.
One of the things that you also continue to ignore is how most families do not have just one unemployed young person in the family; they have young people in a mixture of age groups and their young are engaged in a mixture of activities. Just let us remember this—because we have been through it before and I do not want to go over and over it—two-thirds of the unemployed 18- to 20-year-olds will not be affected by the youth allowance parental means test, either because they are independent themselves or because they come from low income pensioner or beneficiary families. That is the first thing.
The second thing is that, where they have more than one young person in the family and the family income is below $30,700, a family with a student and an unemployed child both aged over 18 will be better off than they are now because the increase in the benefit that is paid to the student is greater than the decrease in the benefit paid to the unemployed person. Those are some of the things you are not factoring in when you are considering this measure. That is why I think you have gone off on your high horse to the wrong destination.
Senator Harradine has acknowledged that this legislation has a lot of benefits. It does have a parental means test to people that you would choose not to parentally means test. But the situation is that those families are parentally means tested now for their students of that age. There is no justifiable reason why they should not also be means tested, using the same means test, for their young unemployed. As I pointed out to you last week, DSS statistics show that the young unemployed are on average on benefits for five months, whereas the students are on assistance for anything up to five years. It is a very different commitment that parents make to their student children from what they are currently asked to make to their young unemployed people.
When there is a transfer within the family of the benefits such as I have just demonstrated to you, it is not fair or honest to suggest that these families are going to be worse off. Many of them will be better off. Although they will get a lesser payment for their young 
 unemployed person, they will be getting an increased benefit for their student. Surely we should be sending a message to young people that, if you possibly can, you should be studying to improve your opportunities in life. The way the current system is designed, you are going to do better financially if you go on the dole than if you go into study, and surely it is wrong to send that message to young people.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I am totally enraged by the minister's response. There are many people who believe that education is a benefit, not a cost, and should be treated so; but it is currently treated as a benefit. The reason there is a difference between education and unemployment for young people is that in no way, shape or form can you call unemployment a benefit—for a young person or anybody else. How dare you come into this chamber and express the fact that a person who is unemployed should be treated as though their unemployment is a benefit to them; that their unemployment is some sort of privilege to them and their families; that unemployment is a gift—something for which they have to be grateful and, if it is taken away, they should expect it.
—What rubbish!  Why don't you listen?
—I was listening when the minister said we should treat unemployment as if it were a training benefit. She said there is no reason why we should expect that unemployment should not be treated as if you were getting an education, and we should somehow expect that a young person who is unemployed has the right to have their family punished as if unemployment were a benefit to that young person. How dare she come into this chamber with that kind of proposal and expect us to accept that!
The real life implications are that a family who may have one unemployed person and who may not have a person who is studying in their house will not feel grateful to you, Minister, when you say, `We have taken this off you but we have given it'—or something fairly small—`to your neighbours or to someone else down the street.' They will not feel 
 grateful, funnily enough. You are suggesting, and we do not believe it, that it averages out. But a family who have had that $121 a week taken off them, funnily enough, will not feel grateful to you or your government. They will not feel that the averages work for them, if they do not have a student at home; they will not feel that it is okay that someone else might get some benefits, if you have taken it off them and they are struggling because they have had over $3,000 a year taken off them—funnily enough, they will not feel grateful and I do not know why they should.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I was a bit astonished by the minister's response, bearing in mind that I did not indulge in personal abuse—I just asked a question—but I will not allow myself to be distracted by that. I point out to the minister that, if she goes back to my speech during the second reading debate, she will see that I stated there were substantial benefits in the bill and we did appreciate those but there were also difficulties. I suppose we do tend to concentrate on the negatives rather than on the positives in this place; but I would appreciate a reasonable answer from the minister rather than the sort of personal response we received earlier.
It appears that certain undertakings have been given in relation to this bill which may affect the outcome. If undertakings have been given that provide families with adult children between the ages of 18 and 20 with some compensation, I will ask the minister again and ignore the other comments: what sort of compensation is anticipated to be provided? It is obviously very relevant to this debate.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—If the minister is going to take on board Senator Neal's questions and concerns, I might add to that even more specifically. Like Senator Dee Margetts, I am similarly angered and getting rather depressed by these proceedings. I do not mean to be cynical or distrusting of governments but I am not happy with a general commitment by the Prime Minister—or anyone else for that matter—to consider how the taxation system can perhaps be restruc 
 tured or changed in some way to alleviate some of the financial burdens on families.
While I agree with that sentiment, I want some specifics. I want to know what is going to happen to the 4,200 young people aged between 18 and 20 who will no longer receive rent assistance—those who will lose at least $74.80 per fortnight or $1,944 per year in income. I want to know what will happen to the 33,600 young people between the ages of 18 and 20 who will receive a reduced level of youth allowance because they will be income tested on parental means. What will happen to the 12,800 young people between the ages of 18 and 20 who will have their benefits cancelled—the ones whom the government does not believe need to live away from home for the purposes of study, jobsearch or training? I could go on. I want to know how these young people are going to be compensated in the short term and how the financial burden on their families is going to be alleviated.
I take on board the minister's comment that a lot of these measures, and some of the measures contained in the bill, have been badly needed for a long time. She is right when she says that there are a number of things that could have been taken on board by the last government. One of those issues is parity between unemployment benefits and student financial assistance levels. Another is flexibility and streamlining of payment arrangements. I know about this—I was in a number of student groups that called on the former government to look into some of the more streamlined arrangements between departments such as DEETYA and the Department of Social Security.
I also acknowledge Senator Dee Margetts's interjection that a number of other issues which have been put forward by a number of community, youth, student and welfare groups have not been picked up in this legislation—whether it is to do with the strict, harsh and restrictive nature of the parental means test under this bill or the inclusion of that absolutely ridiculous actual means testing arrangement.
One issue that I think has been debated longer than most issues in debates on this kind of policy area is the age of independ 
 ence. It is something that we have an opportunity to rectify today, certainly with the amendments before us. I look forward to a recognition from all parties in this chamber—somewhat naively, I suspect—in respect of the age of independence for full-time students.
I remember Senator Neal's very brief rationale, before we went to question time, as to why the ALP will not support the Democrats amendment relating to the definition that the age of independence for a full-time student is 18. She said that it was because a young person in education at that time of their life is advantaged. They certainly are going to be advantaged under a government like this one where education is increasingly defined, as it was under the former government, as a privilege and not a community right! Yes, Senator Margetts, there are people who define education as a benefit and as an investment and not simply a cost.
I still do not understand the logic of the opposition, which is willing to consider a reduction in the age at which a young unemployed person is considered to be independent but not for a full-time student. This is not about being advantaged as a young person by being in the education and training system; this is an expectation under this legislation. Goodness knows what is going to happen to those young people who do not get into an education and training institution, who apply for TAFE places but are dealing with the unmet demand situation of something like 60,000 places last year alone. What happens to those young people who are not able to find some form of employment? How are they going to be compensated? I am still at a loss to understand.
I will acknowledge the positive aspects of this legislation, but I am also going to talk about and expose the harsh ones—throwing 16- and 17 year-olds who cannot get employment, education and training onto some kind of scrap heap. I will acknowledge, too, the few exemptions that exist. I take the government's conservative estimates: 1,600 will be thrown off benefits. What happens to them and their families? I want to know what the minister suggests will happen to those people under this bill. I want to know what 
 happens to them as a consequence of the so-called assurance put forward by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) and the Prime Minister.
I am all for accepting the relevance and the appropriateness of negotiations behind the scenes, debate in committees or even discussions with individuals and party members in this place and with the Prime Minister—anyone. But I expect those amendments, changes, ideas or proposals to be put on the floor of this chamber at the committee stage. I am not going to make a decision on a bill such as this when people are talking about deals and assurances in the backroom. It is absolutely outrageous!

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—One of the themes that has been flowing from this debate about the age of independence is the impact on families. Of course, that is what the government wants us to concentrate on. But we should be talking most specifically about the impact on the unemployed young people. In that light, what sort of guarantees can the Minister for Social Security provide that the income paid to a student in training—let us face it, the allowances are not too generous for students who might be in some sort of training or education; they are just enough to cover that sort of training and education—or an unemployed person will flow to that person?
How do you make a dysfunctional family functional? How do you force income sharing if the young person is not getting along with their family? Heaven knows, this generation did not invent the changes that affect people between the ages of 14 and 18. Some of the changes, disruptions or the dysfunctional nature of families mean that there is no guarantee of an 18- to 25-year-old being able to go to their family and seek assistance if they are unemployed. Can the minister give the committee any assurances about what happens when a family is not prepared to assist—for the very normal reason that families have disagreements with each other—their young family member who is unemployed?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I do not know whether Senator Margetts is confused 
 here, but we are not talking about the under-18-year-olds, in respect of whom the money does go to their parents; we are talking about the over-18-year-olds, to whom the money flows. Why do you have a problem with that?
—Because basically you said it was means tested. How can you say that if they don't get it?
—The quantum is determined by the parents' income. The payment is made to the young person.
—But how can you force the families to give it?
—I find it strange, Senator, that you are in here as an advocate for parents with over $58,000 of income and those are the people who lose benefits altogether if they are living away from home.
—Do you want this debate to go on? I will answer every time you come up with nonsense.
—I know that you have a problem with numbers but, nevertheless, recognise that that is the advice that comes from my department to the Senate as to the income level at which it cuts out. You are advocating, in fact, for the top end of the spectrum. If you lived in my home state of Tasmania you would find that the average family income is just a bit more than half of that.
—Tell me what it is.
—Around $28,000 to $30,000—something in that region. They are accommodated by this and most families will, in fact, not notice any change at all because of the additional measures that are in this bill, such as the abolition of the education leave waiting period—$1,100 extra into that person's pocket which would not go in under the current arrangement—and, in addition, there are the people on Austudy, for example, who are not currently getting anything because their entitlement is under $1,000 and they will now get a proportional entitlement. That is, once again, parentally means tested. The parental means test, as it applies to students and young unemployed people, will be comparable. It is the means test that we have for Austudy now and that has been long 
 established in this country. It is slightly more generous in that you can include a number of other items such as I have mentioned.
You were talking about the young unemployed not getting the money—was it you, Senator Stott Despoja, talking about people having to ask for the money to go for a milkshake? You sounded just like your former leader. I remember very well when she cried out with a song and dance about young people having to ask for the money to go to the pictures, saying that somehow this was going to lead to family strife and it was going to mean we were going to have an increase in the numbers of homeless youth. I think one of you the other day also suggested there would be an increase in sham marriages.
Let me tell you what the facts are. The facts are that when the age of Austudy parental means testing changed there was little or no change in either the number of marriages claimed or the numbers of homeless people. So you can run these stories outside this chamber but the facts do not demonstrate them.
Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—
—It was not Senator Stott Despoja? I am sorry if I have the wrong culprit.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I promise I will confine my remarks to a question, but I cannot let those comments go without seeking clarification. Okay, I acknowledge that you have abolished the $1,000 minimum for those people in relation to Austudy and I acknowledge that 34,200 people will benefit from that. It is a lot. I acknowledge that. And what are their benefits?—a maximum gain of $1,000 per annum compared with—
—And eligibility for rent assistance now.
—We will have this rent assistance debate. As you can see, the Democrats have amendments in relation to the eligibility criteria for rent assistance. We have previously in debates acknowledged the extension of rent assistance to students as something that is welcome but 
 I am sick and tired of the figures being fudged in the sense that, yes, a lot of people will benefit from some of these changes but their benefits are minimal in comparison with some of the losses that people are making.
The minister is shaking her head but in the example I gave in the previous debate of the 1,600 unemployed under-18 year olds, their average loss per fortnight—not per annum—is $176.40. So it just does not weigh up when you are talking about 34,200 benefiting by, on average, $1,000 per annum compared with these people who are losing potentially hundreds of dollars a fortnight. Can you not see that there is a huge discrepancy? We can keep talking about all these people who are going to benefit incrementally, slightly, minimally, compared with those who do lose out, and lose out in a big way.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —As I say, if the minister wants this debate to go on she can keep making those statements that what we are arguing for is the people on high incomes. If the minister will recall, we asked questions specifically about a family on what is considered to be the average weekly ordinary time income of $36,000. We found out that an unemployed young person between the age of 18 and 20 will get the princely sum of $52.70 per fortnight to live on. I think the minister is suggesting that you will not have a situation where, to go out to get a milkshake, a 20-year old will have to ask mum and dad whether they can have the money. To have to ask, just to go out anywhere or to get a bus ticket, is not in the real world. Some $52.70 a fortnight to live on is not high income—this is average, weekly, ordinary time earnings, according to your own figures, Minister.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—I would just like to tease out one tiny bit further the issue that Senator Harradine was addressing a little while back and which I believe is relevant to Senator Stott Despoja's requests. When Senator Harradine was talking about the nature of the potential future commitments of the government he was talking about recognising the transfers that go on when families have to support students, their children and so on. As I recall, he said some 
 thing along the lines that it was only fair in restructuring the tax system that the government recognise those transfers, those extra cost burdens—I guess that is what we are talking about—by minimising the tax that would be paid by those parents, as a compensatory arrangement. I hope that in a garbled way I am reasonably accurately reflecting what Senator Harradine was saying.
I am simply again bringing it back to this issue of young people in this age group. I guess it is a question for the minister. Does the minister agree that it is only fair that the government does recognise those transfers in that way by reducing the tax burden? Is that something that is going to be addressed in this tax restructuring that the government is committed to?
—I have answered it several times already, Senator.
	 Question put:
	 That the requests (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(5)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 124 (lines 25 and 26), omit subsection (4), substitute:
Full-time student aged 21 years or more
(4)	 A person is independent if the person:
	 (a)	 is at least 21 years old; and
	 (b)	 is undertaking full-time study.
Request No. 5 seeks to reduce the age of independence for a full-time student from 25 to 21 years.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Both the Australian Democrats and the Greens (WA) have acknowledged that the age of 21 years is not their preferred option. When I spoke before about the request that the age of independence be reduced to 18, I promised I would talk about some of the views that were given in past inquiries and studies into the age of independence. This could give us some understanding of the contemporary opinion on this matter.
The 1975 TEAS Review Committee, the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee report Foundations for a clever country, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training report on student financial assistance in 1991, the State Youth Affairs Councils and Networks' A living income of May 1992, the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee report on the inquiry into Austudy of June 1995 and the Commonwealth Department of Housing and Regional Development national youth housing strategy final report of December 1995 all said that the age of independence should be 21 years or lower.
Here we have a situation where government departments, community organisations, student groups, legal reform institutions, Australian universities' peak body and committees of 
 both house of this parliament have been suggesting for the last 23 years that the age of independence be set at 21 or below. One is left to wonder just whom the government has been listening to when it says it has conducted wide negotiations and consultations. It seems we would be hard pressed to find anyone outside of this government and perhaps the Treasury department who even vaguely concurs with the age of independence being set at 25. Where does the age of 25 come from?
—They would be in a nursing home before they got there.
—Yes, probably. It is certainly completely unrelated to the legal age of adulthood of 18 years or even the old coming of age at 21. I will tell senators where it comes from: from the old Commonwealth scholarship scheme of 1951. It comes from the very early years of the Liberal Menzies government. This is very telling: while it is clear to most Australians that community values have altered substantially in the last 45 years, including as to when people are responsible for their own affairs, this government seems hell-bent on recreating the values of the 1950s—values to which the Australian community no longer subscribes. I call it compulsory picket fences.
This is why the youth of Australia are turning their back on the government and politicians in general. Senator Stott Despoja probably has figures on the level of dissatisfaction amongst young people with the political process from some of the work she has done, but I believe the youth poll has found it runs at about 98 per cent. While the government continues to ignore the reality for young Australians, this will only get worse.
The age of independence also raises the question as to what is the government's definition of `youth'. For example, what strange biological metamorphosis occurs within the educational environment that renders a student a youth for four years longer than an unemployed person? As the National Union of Students has pointed out, the continuing definition of `youth' status for students aged 21 to 25 goes against one of the central stated aims of the youth allowance 
 scheme: to remove the disincentives to study. Can the minister explain to the chamber how making students dependent on their parents until the age of 25 while rightly maintaining the existing arrangements which allow for anyone aged 21 and above to receive a higher rate of payment on the dole removes disincentives to study?
As the National Union of Students pointed out in its responses to the youth allowance community discussion paper, the greatest transition between study and the labour market for students and unemployed people in receipt of benefits takes place when students leave tertiary education for the first time and begin to look for employment. This process of moving from study to the labour market typically takes place around the age of 21 to 24, as most tertiary students are school leavers undertaking three- to six-year courses. Given this large demographic cohort, the youth allowance age of independence is spectacularly unsuccessful in creating a simplified system and removing disincentives to study.
Remember the minister said it is about making it easier for bureaucrats. As I have demonstrated, the very people who are most likely to transfer between unemployment and education—that is, 21- to 24-year-olds—will still have to leave the youth allowance and register for Newstart or vice versa. So the age of independence for students achieves none of the government's stated objectives.
I agree with the National Union of Students submission that either the government is completely lacking in its understanding of the two systems or the government's claims of wanting to increase flexibility in the transition between education and the labour force are completely disingenuous and the whole age of independence issue is just an excuse to cut benefits to tens of thousands of young, and not so young, Australians.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I ask the minister what the cost of this amendment would be.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I understand that to grant independence to all young people 
 at age 18 would cost in excess of $567 million a year.
—The present amendment before us has the age of independence as 21.
—If a full-time student is independent at age 21 and an unemployed young person is independent at age 18, is that—
—It is just students—
—The answer to the question is that by decreasing the maximum age for youth allowance from 25 years to 21 years for full-time students it would cost approximately $178 million a year.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I will be brief because I understand that we have canvassed a number of these arguments, certainly philosophically, and now it seems economically. My only question to the opposition on this one is whether they are justifying this economically or they are justifying it philosophically. I note Senator Neal has asked the minister for a costing as to what this amendment would mean. I just want to know for the record, if indeed the opposition opposes this amendment, why they are doing it. Just which excuse are we going to be giving the community: is it that it is going to cost too much or is it all those arguments that Senator Neal gave quite eloquently in favour of a reduced age of independence for young unemployed people earlier on in this debate? Don't those arguments apply?
The youth allowance ages are contrary to community expectations and law, as I have said. I just want to make the point on the record that at 15 in this country you can get your own Medicare card. You can have sex—at least heterosexual sex. You can get a full-time or part-time job. At 17 you can be taken to an adult court if you break the law. You can be sent to an adult gaol if the court so orders. You can leave home without legal implications. At 18 you can vote and make a valid will. You are beyond the age of compulsory schooling and you are bound by legal contracts. You can drive a car and you can get married. According to the National 
 Children's and Youth Law Centre, `you are now in control of your life'. So why, oh why, is the age of independence for full-time students 25? As Senator Margetts said, my ambit claim was 18. Our preferred option was at least 18. It was a more realistic indication of when young people in Australia are adults. We are going for 21 now. Boy, I want to see what the opposition does on this one.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—You will be seeing very shortly, so you will not be in suspense for very long. This is a very difficult issue for the opposition. Surely you understand that, bearing in mind the comments you have just made. It has generally been accepted that, for those people who are not in study, their legal adulthood commences at 18. But I think it is also true to say—and I suppose all the reports that were cited by Senator Margetts indicated this—that there is a general acceptance within the community that the age of adulthood for someone in full-time study is somewhat older.
—No, that is not what the report said. They were saying 21 or below; that is what all those reports said. You were not listening.
—I did actually listen quite well. The mere fact that a report says the age should be 21 indicates that is a different age—
—Twenty-one or below.
—Maybe when I sit down you can get up again, if you disagree. It makes it very difficult when you are yelling from your seat. There is an accepted community norm which is different from age 18 for students. I do not believe that young people who are spending their time studying are in exactly the same position as young people who have decided to go out and seek full-time employment. Our position in the past has been, and will be when we are in government, that the age of independence should be reduced from what it was left at with the previous coalition government—from 25 to 21. We were in the process of reducing that age of independence to where it should ultimately rest at the time we lost government. The coalition response, once they were elected, was to take it back up to 25. Our 
 proposition is that it should be once again reduced over time to 21. We do not see that the opposition will be doing it in one go, as has been proposed in this amendment.
—Twenty-one or 22?
—It actually stopped at 22 because of the election. If we had remained in government, the objective was to take it down to 21. That was the ultimate aim. An amendment was foreshadowed by Senator Carr which proposed that the age be reduced over time from 25. I understand that is somewhere in the workings still. That is ultimately our position—that we would like to see it reduced from 25—but we cannot see that occurring in one go, as is proposed here.
When you are on the crossbenches and do not have to make some of the really tough decisions as to priority, it is extraordinarily easy just to say, `We will spend it all on this particular amendment.' I assume the figure of $178 million is at least roughly correct. When you have to weigh it up against all sorts of other demands—including services for people who are unemployed, child care, tax benefits for low income earners—there are extraordinarily tight and difficult decisions that have to be made about priorities.
Though the opposition would ultimately like to see the payment for students based on an age of independence of 21, we cannot see that being done instantly. That is why we cannot at this stage support the Democrats request that is before us. I know, in terms of the Democrats pushing all the right political buttons, it is probably very gratifying to them and I am sure that they will make hay while the sun shines.
—Young people vote, too.
—I am very aware of the fact that young people vote, and I am very aware, as a former student, that I relied on income provided by Austudy when I became old enough to be treated as an independent. But, that all being true and being very well aware of how difficult financial circumstances can be for students, it still remains that the priority decision made is that the age of independence should be reduced over time 
 and not instantly. I am sure the Democrats would prefer a simple and instant answer, but in life things are not always instant or easy. This is one of those difficult propositions. There have been many groups in the community—
—Twenty years this debate has been going on. This is not an instant answer.
—And the debate for rent assistance has been 20 years, too, and you got it.
—Maybe I will sit down and allow the government and the crossbenchers to slang at each other.
	 Question put:
	 That the request (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(13)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (after line 12), after subsection (11), insert:
Unemployed people aged 18 years or more
(11A)	 A person is independent if the person:
	 (a)	 is at least 18 years old; and
	 (b)	 is not undertaking full-time study.
This request seeks essentially to retain the age of independence at 18 for young people who are unemployed. Many of the issues have been canvassed. Contrary to what the minister might believe, I am trying to facilitate the progress of this bill. The record shows that the Democrats believe that 18 is an appropriate age for young people to establish their independence—and this is comparable to the Greens' (WA) amendments and intentions.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —This is exactly the same as our amendment—the one we have already lost—isn't it? Does it bring down the age of independence for young unemployed to 18 years?

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I did not think that this was withdrawn or redundant as a consequence of the failure of your amendment. From memory, your amendment related to the age at which people could enter into youth allowance activity agreements.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I can give you a preliminary answer which I might have to correct in a minute. I understand that the opposition's amendment was setting the maximum age for youth allowance for unemployed at 18.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —There were two separate amendments. One was to set the maximum and one was to define the age of independence. I have been advised that the effect of our amendments is identical but come about through different means. You are open to move it.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I am happy to proceed with this request. I do not see a problem dealing with this separately. We are probably after the same ends but to be on the safe side I will continue with this request.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—Our position is that for those unemployed young persons the age of independence should commence at 18. So the opposition will be supporting this request.
	 Question put:
	 That the request (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —The remaining requests on the running sheet are all procedural ones following on from what we have been debating already. Are senators prepared to withdraw them if the motions have been lost previously?

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—No, I will not withdraw them, but nor will I pursue a division on them because the result will be what we have seen—the government and Senator Harradine using the numbers to vote down any changes which would have put some of that $560 million that has been taken out of the pockets of young people back into their pockets. I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(4)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 124 (after line 26), after subsection (4), insert:
Full-time student aged 21 years or more
(4A)	 A person is independent if the person:
	 (a)	 is at least 21 years old; and
	 (b)	 is undertaking full-time study.
In relation to my requests for amendments Nos 4 and 5 for the Australian Greens, I would have preferred the Greens (WA) position of making 18 the year of adulthood for people in all circumstances, including their rights to benefits. I predict that the committee will not vote that way, because the government and Senator Harradine will not support that position.
I will call a spade a spade. It is $560 million all-up that will be taken out of the pockets of young Australians. You can measure a civil society pretty well by the extra effort—and that includes money—that goes to the more disadvantaged people in that society. The success of this piece of legislation is the 
 reverse—you measure it by the amount of money it will take out of the pockets of already disadvantaged people. That is the direction that the government is going in general. It is against a civil society. It is against a society that is moving under the flag of a fair go for everyone.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.
—The committee is considering the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997  and request for amendment No. 4 on sheet 859 moved by Senator Brown. The question is that the request be agreed to.
Request not agreed to.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(5)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (after line 12), after subsection (11), insert:
Unemployed people aged 18 years or more
(11A)	 A person is independent if the person:
	 (a)	 is at least 18 years old; and
	 (b)	 is not undertaking full-time study.
The effect of request for amendment No. 5 is to reduce the age for students from 25 as in the government legislation to 21. We are not going to get any alteration from the government. The Democrats have already tried to amend this. I prefer the Greens (Western Australia) amendment which would reduce the age to 18. I will not pursue this amendment, nor will I relent on the justice of the amendment as against the government's legislation.
Request not agreed to.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(6)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (lines 13 to 26), omit subsection (12), substitute:
People who are disadvantaged
(12)	 A person is independent if the person is at least 16 years old and one or more of the following apply: 

	 (a)	 the person has full-time employment of at least 30 hours per week for a period of at least 12 months, or for periods that take at least 12 months; or
	 (b)	 the person does not live at the home of either or both of his or her parents; or
	 (c)	 in the Secretary's opinion, the person is specially disadvantaged with respect to education or employment; or
	 (d)	 the person is not receiving adequate financial support that is at least equal to the rate of payment the person would be entitled to if he or she was receiving youth allowance.
Note:	 For  parent  see section 5 (paragraph (a) of that definition).
Request for amendment No. 6 reduces the age for the disadvantaged test from 18 to 16 and makes the definition of independence more flexible so that, instead of having to meet all criteria, applicants would need to meet only one of the very strict criteria. These criteria are so onerous that there will be very few people who will be able to qualify. Our amendments would mean that people who are disadvantaged under one or other of the government's criteria would be able to qualify.
The government has to pull in its belt. In doing so, it is going to take the belt to young people. This legislation is about robbing and cheating young people of not just tens of millions of dollars but hundreds of millions of dollars. As the minister has said, it is to try to encourage young people to go into education, but at the other end governments are cutting funds to education. For example, in TAFE courses 60,000 people last year could not find a place so the increased number is going to be blocked from that avenue.
It will no doubt suit the government to continue to say, as the minister has quite erroneously said, that people who are opposed to what she is doing are in favour of rich people getting an advantage as a part spin-off from the government's legislation. The fact is that this is another effort by the Greens to roll back the disadvantage to disadvantaged young people, to make the disadvantage test less onerous. The government wants to make the disadvantage to disadvantaged young people more onerous, because it wants to take money 
 out of their pocket. It wants to force them to be mendicants on their parents, and it wants to transfer its cost cutting obligations to a more expensive life of disadvantage and therefore a more disadvantaged life for those people in our society who are least able to do anything about it. The numbers will be with the government. Senator Harradine is going to vote for this social disadvantage being increased—for what good reason I do not know. There are no specifics that I have been able to pick up on, but he is going to vote for this enormous impost on young people and the impact it will have on poor families.
The minister says that the difference between the government legislation and reducing the age to 18 alone for students and unemployed people being treated as adults would be some $560 million. This measure would make that figure greater. It is a massive incursion on disadvantaged people in Australia. I do not understand how Senator Harradine can support it, but he does. I do not understand how the government can glibly say this is to the advantage of young Australians because it is not. I put the amendment to the Senate knowing that it has a snowflake's chance in hell of getting through because of the cold face of people on the other side to the disadvantaged people in our society.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —A lot of the comments made by Senator Brown I feel the need to respond to. It may well be your intention to do what you describe, Senator Brown, but the way you have framed your amendment essentially means that anyone who satisfies the requirement of being age 18 is eligible for this payment. We would be happy to do that for the unemployed, as we have stated, but your amendment has the effect of including everyone who is 18—students or the unemployed. That being the case—and I do not know what your intention was—we have already stated our position. We will not be supporting it.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—My intention is to loosen up the disadvantage test so that more disadvantaged people are able to have access to benefits. It is as simple as that. If Labor wants to oppose that, then Labor may oppose it.
Request not agreed to.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(7)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 125 (line 8), omit "of at least 10 years".
This request has the effect of deleting the requirement that, for the purpose of being independent, both parents have to be in gaol for a minimum of 10 years. We are of the view that if your parents are in gaol, no matter for what period, that you must be regarded as independent. I think the government has reassessed its position and will be accepting it, so I will not go on.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —That is correct. The government will not be opposing opposition request for amendment No. 7, but we will be opposing opposition request No. 8.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Opposition amendment No. 7 obviously will have the support of the Greens WA because our amendment is effectively the same. If I am not incorrect, it is also the same as the Australian Democrats amendment. So it looks as though there is very strong support for not requiring people, before their being declared independent, to have their parents in prison for 10 years.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—As Senator Margetts has pointed out, the Democrats have a similar amendment. I found the original part of this bill quite extraordinary. Regardless of whether the sole parent is, or both parents are, in prison for 10 weeks or 10 years, as it is specified in this case, I would think it pretty obvious that during such time they would not necessarily be able to support their children. So I am glad to see that the government has accepted that logic.
Request agreed to.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment: 

(8)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (line 17), after subparagraph (ii), insert:
	 ; or (iii) 	 are unable to provide the person with a suitable home because they lack stable accommodation;
The purpose of this request is to say that, where parents are unable to provide their children with a home because they themselves are homeless, that child is regarded as being independent.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —This comes down—and it is a pity that the government has indicated that they will not be supporting this—to the very point that I was making before: that you will have situations where parents, basically, are not able, or refuse, to provide that support base for their adult children; and it is totally outrageous to suggest that somehow or other those people will be left destitute. That appears to be what the government is doing, and I would support the opposition's amendment on this.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —I am waiting to hear from the government as to why this measure that has been moved by Senator Neal has been an absolutely crucial amendment which would not in any circumstances be accepted by the government. I am wondering, first of all, whether Senator Neal could oblige the committee with just rerunning it. It was very short time. There are time constraints, of course, but I would be grateful if she could rerun the argument.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—At present the act provides that, where a person cannot live with their parents because of sexual abuse or violence in the home, they are regarded as being independent. The act is presently moot on the point of a situation where, in fact, the parents themselves do not have a home that they can provide for their children. It can be because of their adverse financial circumstances—although that is probably unlikely because of the level of the means test. Alternatively, it may be that they do not have a permanent address—people living in caravans, travelling around, doing a world tour. Anything of that nature would mean that the parents do not have a home they can provide for their chil 
 dren. In that situation, the opposition believes that those adult children should be treated as independent.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—We do not support the amendment because, in our view, it is too broad. Young people concurrently qualify as independent when there is no parental home and the parents cannot accommodate the young person. For example, there is the situation of a woman who has to move to a refuge; she may not be able to accommodate her teenage son at the refuge. The current provisions would allow for that, and most such situations would be temporary.
If we were to move to broadening this, as suggested by these amendments, parents have a responsibility to provide a home for their children. It is only in unusual circumstances that the independent rate would be paid. A parent's refusal, on the other hand, to have the young person live at home is not enough on its own to qualify. It needs to be assessed in the context of whether extreme family breakdown has occurred. I would draw the Senate's attention to the fact that, if we simply accepted the statement that a young person is not allowed to live at home as evidence of homelessness, we would be inviting collusion between parents and children.
Senator Harradine, you may recall that, under the previous government, there was a lot of scepticism about the way that the homeless criteria were being administered. The member for Braddon, Chris Miles, and I waged a vigorous campaign to ensure that parents were included in the assessment by the social workers in the then Department of Social Security to see whether the young person's claims were true. It may be that in some cases the young person claimed that they were homeless when, in fact, they were not; that there was a family willing and keen to care for them. In some cases, there may well have been irresponsible parents who were prepared to collude with their child because the child was saying that they wanted to leave home and could get the money from the government. I am concerned that, if we 
 are not careful about this measure, we open up these sorts of situations.
As I understand it, the arrangements as they are here in this legislation are the same as are currently for youth training allowance; they are no harsher. What has happened since this government has been in office is that we have had a very careful look at the criteria and the way they are administered. But that is simply to make sure that those who are entitled do get their entitlement, and that those who are not do not abuse the taxpayer. I believe that there was an element of that in the way it was administered previously. I do not see any justification for expanding this and making it broader so that you can have families wrongfully claiming for support when they are perfectly able to provide a home for their child.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I do not know, Minister, whether you are intentionally misstating the effect of our amendment or you really do not understand. Our amendment does not extend to circumstances where parents refuse to have children at home. That is not included in our amendment and it is not envisaged to do so. All it does is cover a situation where the parents themselves do not have a home that their children, adult or under 18, can reside in. To say otherwise, to say it is extended to circumstances where parents might refuse, is not true.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I would not have wanted to mislead the Senate. I guess I was using a suggested response which actually applies to more than one of the amendments in this area. The amendment that is moved by Senator Neal for the opposition in fact does enable payment of the higher rate of youth allowance to young people whose parents do not have a home. Other similar exceptional circumstances include situations where parents are unable to provide a home for the young person because they themselves are homeless or in temporary accommodation because of a major personal crisis. I was referring to that earlier in my response. But extending the qualifications may encourage parents to rearrange their accommodation 
 without fulfilling their primary responsibility to house their children. Parents who choose to move to new premises or interstate are still required and expected to make arrangements for their children to remain or to go with them, not to artificially cause them to be homeless and for the taxpayer to support them in that way. Where the parental home is not conducive to study or job search, for example because the parents have an itinerant lifestyle, the young person may in fact receive the away from home rate of youth allowance.
