So, Senator, I am sorry if I gave you some information you are not yet ready to receive in relation to Senator Stott-Despoja's subsequent amendment, but I have now given you the government's response focusing on your amendment alone.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I really find it hard to believe that there are large numbers of parents in the community who would intentionally make themselves homeless for the purpose of avoiding the independence test for the youth allowance. It seems a preposterous suggestion. In terms of the example that the minister gave about a parent moving into temporary accommodation in a refuge, that particular circumstance is covered by the bill presently because it relates to circumstances of domestic violence. So essentially what has happened is that the government has covered one possible example of the cause of homelessness, which is domestic violence, but in my view there are many possible causes for homelessness in the parents' circumstances and I think that, whatever the cause of their homelessness, you still cannot expect that a young person will do without support because of that parental situation.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Perhaps I could throw a question back to Senator Neal. If parents decided that they wanted to take a year off and take a tour around Australia and they had a young person in their care who fitted these criteria, would you regard it as being responsible of the parents to make no proper arrangements for their young person when they left? I would have thought your answer to that would have been no, but if you 
 want to say yes, you think it is proper, I would be surprised.
—When you sit down, I will answer.
—You're the one doing it to people; now you're blaming the parents.
—Order! Hopefully we can conduct this discussion in an orderly and cordial way.
—Mr Chairman, as you may know, I worked for a state Labor government on child protection for a number of years, so I certainly have a good understanding that some parents in this country are irresponsible; very few, but some are. It does not matter whether we are talking about babies, toddlers, primary school children or older young people, it is not acceptable for parents not to take on their responsibilities to the children they bring into the world. If parents were in fact to take this trip around Australia, which can be a great experience for anybody, we would expect them to make proper provision, whether by way of a family member to act in their place while they are gone or to pay for stable and reasonable accommodation for the young person. I hope you would see that we should not allow this to be broadened to allow similar circumstances to that, to allow people to shrug their shoulders and let the taxpayer provide.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—This bill really is not about making moral judgments about particular parents. You may say it is responsible or not responsible—
—Don't you? It is abandoning your child.
—Or adult, as the case may be.
—That is not the question. Whether we can say the parent has behaved badly or not, the repercussions of that behaviour, even if we make moral judgments about it being wrong, do not rebound on the parent. If you are actually going to collect the money from the parents and then pay it on to the children, I suppose to some extent I could understand your argument. But if you are saying that the parents have done something that you think is morally bad and therefore we 
 should punish the children by leaving them unsupported, I really do not understand the logic in that. If a parent is not providing a home for the children, whether or not you make the moral judgment that that is wrong, I think some people would have dispute with your view that past the age of 18 parents have a moral responsibility to support their children. I do not think that is the accepted view, that once you have children you have to support them until the day they die.
There are some community groups that believe that you have a responsibility to support your parents as well. That is not a view that we have included in our law, although I understand that they have in some countries such as Singapore. I do not think it is universally accepted that, once you have a child, you must support them until whatever age. But putting that argument aside for the moment, I do not believe we can punish the child of one of those parents who has not behaved properly by depriving them of support.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —Just a further question to the minister on that level: I wonder whether we could clarify it by putting in the legislation the example of the working couple who are perhaps close to the age of retirement and who have finally saved up enough to get in their camper van and go around Australia on whatever superannuation might be left to them. Perhaps you could write into the legislation that, if they are renting a house, they will have to take their 20-year-old with them and that would be a really nice way to spend their retirement trip going around Australia in their camper van.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The amendment is that they are `unable to provide the person with a suitable home because they lack stable accommodation'. If they are homeless and they have their young person with them, then the entitlements do flow. If they set out to deliberately not have stable accommodation, then why should their neighbour be asked to support their child?  
—They are adult.
—They are a financially dependant child while they are on these payments just as they are up to the age of 25 if they are a student. Is it right that parents should be abrogating their responsibility and handing it over to their neighbours without making proper arrangements for the accommodation of their child? If they were homeless and they were together, that would be a different matter—they would be entitled.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —This sort of red herring that the minister keeps raising about these irresponsible parents who intentionally become homeless themselves is quite preposterous. Some people's lifestyles quite validly involve moving around—occupations such as fruit picker, people who run shows and construction workers. There is a whole raft of lifestyles that provide some families with incomes all around Australia. We are not all professionals and small businessmen. Some people do have a shifting lifestyle. In those circumstances, I think we still have to support their children and to accept that particular variation from the middle-class norm.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—Senator Neal has made a very good point. It is one that I was going to raise. It is something that the minister should have a look at. I do not know how far it goes, but there may be some response. The example that was given by Senator Neal is a very good one. There are quite a number of people who are working casually in a particular industry. Shearers are another example.
—I was waiting for that.
—I thought you might have been, Mr Chairman. One of the purposes of this legislation is to encourage persons to get into work and to retain their work. Here is a situation whereby this might work in the other direction. I wonder whether you would be good enough to respond to the very valid point that Senator Neal has just made.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Can I give you another example: if a shearer is travelling 
 around Australia taking work as he goes and he has his young person with him—
—Him or her!
—Yes, there are some female shearers now, aren't there? If there is no extreme family breakdown, the young person could receive the at home or away if appropriate but subject to the parental means test. The circumstances are that if there is extreme family breakdown then the young person would be deemed to be eligible because of independence criteria. The safety net is there, but the opposition's amendment is just extending the clause too widely.
—Not all families live like you.
—No, and I do not suppose they live like you either.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —We are not talking about the question of extreme family breakdown; we are talking about a working situation in which many people find themselves. It just seems to me that you are almost condemning—perhaps I am going too far here—the young people to shift with their parents when those parents are in the type of work such as described by Senator Neal. Or, indeed, it must be somewhere in the legislation that if a parent does have a transfer in a particular job from, say, Hobart to Melbourne, then the students or the unemployed aged 18, 19 and 20 surely do not have to shift. But, by the same token, I think you would need to do something to cater for the group that Senator Neal pointed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Some of the current limitations in the unreasonable live-at-home provisions have been made clear to this chamber by virtue of the fact that at least three separate sets of amendments, albeit in slight conflict with one another, have been moved to try to value-add or improve this section in some way. I concur with the sentiments of Senators Neal, Margetts and Harradine in the debate so far. Of course, we think the Democrats amendment is the best one. 
Suffice to say, I am prepared to support the amendments moved by the other two parties because it is really important that we improve this section so that it does not simply take into account extreme situations—albeit it should take into account extreme situations in family and home life where it may be deemed unreasonable to live at home—but also some of the slightly unusual circumstances. Some of those have been described. As in this amendment's case, it may be the inability of a family to provide a stable home environment or it may have to do with itinerant work, or what have you. It has been demonstrated quite clearly to this chamber that such consideration should be included in the determination of this particular criteria.
The Democrats amendment is more comprehensive. However, we have all taken into account bits and pieces of not only the current provision but also each other's. I speak very much in favour of all the amendments so far but commend ours when the debate moves on. Minister, I implore you to take into account some of the issues that have been raised in this committee stage. I do not think that this part of the bill as proposed can stay as it stands.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I hear the sentiments expressed by honourable senators. I emphasise that the government does not believe that people should be able to choose to not be subject to the parental means test. That is our concern in this area. Maybe the opposition will be prepared to consider inserting some words into their amendment which the government would be prepared to accept—after the words `or (iii)', insert the words `for reasons beyond the parents control are unable to provide the person with a suitable home'.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—It really does not satisfy the problem. If you are an itinerant worker—I do not really like that term, but I suppose it describes it—and you choose to move around to follow a job, it is not for reasons beyond your control; you choose to pack up and move to the next place. You are not forced to do it. It is just 
 your particular lifestyle. It really does not deal with that problem.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—In the case of where the parental home is not conducive to study or Jobsearch, such as in the case of an itinerant lifestyle, the young person may receive the away-from-home rate of youth allowance. I do not think that that is sufficient objection, Senator. Do you want time to think about it?
—No.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I put this into context. Remember, when we talk about industrial relations we talk about the fact that people can choose to take or not take a job.
—They demand flexibility in the workplace.
—That is right. But here we have a situation where people, in order to earn a living, either have chosen a lifestyle or have not had a great deal of choice and follow a lifestyle in order to earn a living. It might be fruit picking or rodeos. Perhaps we can have a special program all over Australia and people can ring in with their examples of where it is going to be a ridiculous situation—for instance, when an otherwise independent 20-year-old is going to have to travel around Australia with their parents—
—In a campervan.
—in a campervan, to the great joy of both the 20-year-old and the parents.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I think the government needs a little bit more time to think about this. I am inclined to vote for the amendment as it is and see what happens later.
Request agreed to.
—Senator Stott Despoja, do you intend to move amendment 8? Senator Margetts, do the Greens (WA) intend to move amendment No.16?

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Our understanding is that the passage of opposition amendment No. 7 ensured that our concerns were taken care of. Does that mean we are up to Democrat amendment No. 9?
—That will depend on what Senator Margetts has to say.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I  am rapturous to see that at least opposition amendment No. 7, which is the same as Democrats amendment No. 8 and Greens (WA) amendment No. 16, was passed. Therefore, it is not necessary for those to be put.
—Senator Stott Despoja, I have a note here which advises that your amendment 9 is in conflict with the amendment that we have just dealt with—amendment 7. Is it your intention to now not proceed with that?

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I think you are referring to opposition amendment No. 8, with which it was in conflict. Number 7 was the same as Democrats amendment No. 8. I acknowledge Democrats amendment No. 9 is in conflict with opposition amendment No. 8. I seek advice from the chamber. I recognise it is in conflict, but, as I mentioned, I think it is a good and a more comprehensive amendment. Is there reason why I cannot pursue the Democrats preferred definition of what is unreasonable circumstances for living at home?
—Senator Stott Despoja, the ball is in your court. You certainly can move the amendment and it is really up to the honourable senators to then decide how they are going to vote on it.
—Fair enough. I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(9)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (lines 8 to 25), omit subsection (9), substitute:
Unreasonable to live at home
(9)	 A person is independent if: 

	 (a)	 the person cannot live at the home of either or both of his or her parents:
		 (i)	 because it would be unreasonable to expect the person to do so as there would be a serious risk to his or her physical or mental well-being due to violence, sexual abuse or other similar unreasonable circumstances; or
		 (ii)	 because there is no parental home or homes; or
		 (iii)	 because the parents refuse to provide a home; or
		 (iv)	 because of extreme family breakdown or other similar exceptional circumstances; and
	 (b)	 the person is not receiving adequate and continuous support.
As I said, the amendment substitutes `unreasonable to live at home' with a new definition. This amendment, I believe, is more comprehensive than the Greens (WA) amendment to follow or the amendment just moved by the opposition. We seek to ensure that young people who are genuinely independent of or not supported by their parents are not forced to become or, indeed, to remain homeless. If it is unreasonable that they live in the parental home, and no other support of a continuous nature is available, then they will be eligible for the independent rate and they will not be assessed according to the means of the very people who cannot or will not support them.
We seek to achieve a similar purpose to that of the amendment we have just dealt with and the Greens one to follow but, again, we think that perhaps we have encompassed some of their concerns, whether they relate to the issue of continuity of support or a range of other potential problems that have been taken into account with this amendment.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I must say that I am at a bit of a loss to understand why the Democrats are proceeding with this. Obviously the amendment was constructed in a slightly different way but the end result seems to be much the same. I am a little bit concerned about the effect of having two amendments lumped on top of each other and attacking different parts of the legislation. Unless the Democrats can explain 
 to me what additional advantage we will gain from this I am a bit loath to support it.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—As I outlined, what the opposition amendment has done is insert an additional line in relation to being unable to provide a person with a suitable home because they lack stable accommodation. What the Democrats and the Greens have done in consultation with the Welfare Rights Centre and other people is to draft an amendment which takes into account some of the sentiments and the gist of the government proposal—but we think it is more refined and comprehensive.
The reason we are proceeding with this is that we think it is a better amendment and it takes into account a range of other provisions including the lack of parental home or homes and the parental refusal to provide home or homes. We think ours is drafted in a better fashion. It is simply up to you, Senator Neal, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, as to whether you like it. We took on board a number of concerns and drafted this in a way that is different from your amendment; and, with all due respect, it is better.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The opposition's amendment No. 8 states:
(8)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (line 17), after subparagraph (ii), insert:
	 ; or (iii) 	 are unable to provide the person with a suitable home because they lack stable accommodation;
Certainly, the proposed amendments by the Greens (WA) add something else to that. Our amendment No. 17 largely is covered under what occurred in relation to opposition amendment No. 8 but there are other elements of it in relation to continuous support which have not been addressed in the opposition's amendment.
Senator Stott Despoja's amendment talks about a person not receiving adequate and continuous support. The main difference between that and the Greens (WA) amendment is that we have defined `adequate' as an amount which is equivalent to the maximum rate of youth allowance. That is for when you 
 are at home but your parents are not giving you any money. Just because you are at home does not mean you are going to get any support. Either way, if there were support for Senator Stott Despoja's amendment in relation to that I would think it would be a step forward.
Contrary to the advice we have just been given by Senator Neal, I think only some elements of those amendments are covered by the opposition's amendments and there are some improvements that can be made. I would be prepared to accept `not receiving adequate and continuous support', although to define it might have been useful.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I acknowledge that as one component of our criteria we have one of the same aspects as the government's. That is because we thought it was an appropriate and good part of the eligibility criteria. We probably could have drafted the amendment around it but because we are substituting that proposed section we included that.
—It was well phrased.
—I think the government would like to hear that it is well phrased too. The difference—this is again a feature of the Greens (WA) amendment—is that, along with that particular provision, we specify, `because there is no parental home or homes; or because the parents refuse to provide a home.' That is my answer to Senator Neal as well. That is a major distinction and one that I would have thought was included in the opposition amendments. That is a fundamental difference and one that we 
 consider, as I am sure you would agree, Mr Temporary Chairman, quite important.
I take on board Senator Margetts's additions in the way that she has measured the level of continuous support against the youth allowance. I think that is an appropriate way to go.
Request not agreed to.
—We now move to Greens (WA) amendments Nos. 17 and 19. Do you intend to move those, Senator Margetts?

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I think there is no need to move amendment 17 now because we have at least got an improvement on the issue of parental homes and compulsory movement of 20-year-olds around the country. It would seem quite obvious that there is little  support for getting fair and reasonable support for young people if they are at home. If they are not receiving it, it looks like they are not going to get the support of the government and potentially the opposition. So I will not be moving amendment 19.
—What about 18?
—I assume, Senator Margetts, that that is inclusive of amendment 18?
—Yes. To a certain extent, I think my amendment 18 may not be in conflict with what other people are doing. Amendment 19 related to a person `not receiving adequate and continuous support, whether directly or indirectly and whether financial or otherwise, at an amount which is equivalent to the maximum rate of Youth Allowance'. Amendment 18 was substituting `a person cannot' with `it is unreasonable for the person to'.
I seek leave to move those amendments because I think it is worthwhile putting them to the Senate. It is part of the debate we have had about what is reasonable and what is unreasonable. I think there should be the ability for discretion to be used in this case. When you have to prove that a person cannot, firstly, it can be very intrusive and, secondly, it can be very difficult in a family situation which may already be extremely difficult and also very difficult for people to try to prove. 
 I think unreasonability is better than to have something in legislation which says that the person cannot, because that becomes very difficult to actually prove.
—You are seeking leave to move amendments 18 and 19. Is leave granted?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I suppose it is. Senator, have you had a look at what the impact would be if we agreed to your amendment 18? I was just getting advice on it.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I thought we had dealt with amendments 17 and 19. I thought we had a vote on it.
—No. Initially Senator Margetts withdrew from moving amendments 17 to 19. The question came up about amendment 18 from the minister. On reconsidering the issue, Senator Margetts has now sought leave to move amendments 18 and 19.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I am advised that the impact of amendment 18 would be that we would have a provision that says, `It is unreasonable to live at home because it is unreasonable to live at home.' Maybe you do not intend that.
—Senator Margetts, leave has been granted for you to move your amendments. Please do so.
Requests (Senator Margetts's)—by leave—proposed:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(18)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (line 10), omit "the person cannot", substitute "it is unreasonable for the person to".
(19)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (lines 18 to 21), omit paragraph (9)(b), substitute:
(b)	 the person is not receiving adequate and continuous support, whether directly or indirectly and whether financial or otherwise, at an amount which is equivalent to the maximum rate of Youth Allowance; and

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I have just put the proposition to Senator Margetts for 
 her consideration. She may not wish to proceed with amendment 18 in the circumstances.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I do not actually think it is unreasonable. Line (10) starts with the words, `A person is independent'. We are substituting `cannot' with `it is unreasonable for the person to live at the home of either or both of his or her parents'. Then it has the reasons why. I think you should perhaps read it again, Minister. I see now—`unreasonable to live at home'.
—The first element is `because it is unreasonable to live at home'. It is repetitive.
—This is actually a subtitle—`Unreasonable to live at home'. It says, `A person is independent if the person cannot', et cetera.
—`It is unreasonable to live at home'.
—You have got subtitles, such as `Person who is self-supporting'. They are in italics and I am assuming they are a broad description of what is underneath it.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —Senator, if you want to have that amendment, you have it. We will call it `the Margetts amendment' and all it does is look like poor drafting. It is not going to change anything.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—There is much in this legislation which is more than poor drafting, I would have to say, and this is not a sentence. You cannot read it, `It is unreasonable to live at home because it is unreasonable to live at home'. It is actually in italics, as in, `People who are self-supporting'. The next section does not say, `People who are self-supporting because people who are self-supporting'.
—Perhaps we might progress a little. As I understand, Minister, you said you were going to agree with the amendments. Is that correct?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—If she wants 
 it so badly. I think Senator Margetts is simply hung up on the heading `Unreasonable to live at home'.
—It's you who's unreasonable.
—No, you have to look further down, Senator. You are inserting the words `unreasonable to live at home'. Look down at (ii)—`because it would be unreasonable to expect the person to do so'. That is where it is repetitive drafting. If you want to have it as your memorial, then so be it.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I must say I find it very difficult to understand how this in any way changes the legislation as it stands. But, if a church can split over an iota, I suppose this chamber can split over two words.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I would like the final word. It is really interesting that the minister had that argument, considering she has a subtitle `Unreasonable' and then said the person cannot. They are talking about unreasonableness and in fact saying unreasonableness means impossibility. I think they are different, and I was trying to make them match.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I hate to stop Senator Margetts having the last word but I did want to rise briefly in support of her amendment 19—extending the provision so that not only is the young person receiving adequate and continuous support, but that support is measured against the standard of the youth allowance. That seems entirely reasonable.
We do not think it is a particularly unduly or liberal request, given that it will apply only when the parent has absolved himself or herself of responsibility towards that young person by the previously mentioned conditions—for example, through violence, abuse, refusal of the parents to allow the young person to live in the parental home, et cetera. I think amendment 19 is a good amendment. I hope that the opposition will support it.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I have to say I think there are again serious problems with the drafting of 19. In 
 terms of the intended principle, it would be very difficult to assess. But, putting that aside for the moment, in my opinion the amendment as presently worded says that if any parent provides less than the equivalent youth allowance, no matter how little less than the whole youth allowance, the person becomes eligible for the entire independent youth allowance. I do not know whether that is what you intended but it seems to say that.
Requests not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(10)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (line 31), omit "20 hours", substitute "15 hours".
We have moved this amendment to the section relating to people who are self-supporting for the purposes of establishing their independence. The change is to (b)—`part-time employment of at least 20 hours per week for at least 2 years since the person last left secondary school'. The Democrat amendment omits `20 hours' and substitutes `15 hours'.
We have moved this amendment in recognition that the criteria for independence in this bill have been made far too stringent. We are also aware of the government's attitude and policy—we have been debating it most of today—towards independence definitions. In fact, on 26 August last year, when asked in question time why the government had changed the definition of an employment placement for the purposes of paying a success fee for new private employment agencies from 20 hours a week to 15 hours a week, oddly enough, and additionally whether the government believed 15 hours a week was a real job, the former minister responded:
. . . the purpose of the employment services reforms is to make you independent, to give you sufficient work that you could at least say, `I am now responsible for myself,' and no longer be dependent. The calculation is that about that level of hours a week is when you will be in that position.
If 15 hours was good enough for the former minister, then why isn't it good enough now? 
 Why not be consistent in this particular legislation? I hope that we are not setting another double standard.
First of all, I would like to ask the government why the government chose the 20-hour figure per week for that two-year period as the criteria for independence. Perhaps this is based on Working Nation.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—It might short-circuit things a bit if I indicate that the government is prepared to accept this amendment. It is also prepared to accept the next amendments—11 and 12—from the Democrats and amendment 20 from the Greens (WA).
—I thank the minister.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—As can be seen from the sheet, there is a fair amount of common ground between these amendments. I indicate that we believe that the Greens (WA) amendment 20 is slightly different from the Australian Democrat amendment 10 but is subsumed into Democrat amendment 11 and the effect is the same. If Senator Stott Despoja puts Democrat amendments 10, 11 and 12, we will be prepared to support all three.
—And withdraw yours.
—Yes.
—Senator Stott Despoja, would you like to move amendments 11 and 12 in addition to amendment 10, which you have already moved?
Requests (by Senator Stott Despoja) agreed to:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(11)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 126 (line 34) to page 127 (line 1), omit "50% of average weekly earnings", substitute "the equivalent of 75% of the maximum Commonwealth training award payments".
(12)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (lines 5 to 12), omit subsection (11).
Request (by Senator Margetts, at the request of Senator Brown) not agreed to:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(7)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 127 (after line 26), at the end of section 1967A, add:
When is a 15 year old regarded as independent
(13)	 A person is independent if the person:
	 (a)	 is at least 15 years old but under 16 years old; and
	 (b)	 would be entitled to receive youth allowance if the person had been at least 16 years old; and
	 (c)	 satisfies the Secretary that the person:
		 (i)	 has an employment history involving full-time employment that was on either a permanent basis or a regular casual basis; or
		 (ii)	 has received an offer of employment of that kind but has been unable to take up the offer for reasons beyond his or her control; or
		 (iii)	 has been registered as being unemployed for at least 13 weeks; and
	 (d)	 either:
		 (i)	 has reached the minimum school leaving age for the State or Territory in which the person is living; or
		 (ii)	 has been granted a formal exemption from attending school by the education authority of that State or Territory.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(21)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 128 (line 20), after "opposite", insert "or same".
(24)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 129 (line 18), after "opposite", insert "or same".
This relates to changes to the definition of `youth allowance couple' and it includes same sex relationships. Basically a person is classed as independent if they are part of a youth allowance couple. There is no reason why we need to discriminate against same sex couples if they are covered under the normal criteria. There is no reason at all to actually single out a group of people and say, `You've satisfied all the other criteria except that you're a couple of the same sex.' I urge the Senate to support commonsense in relation to Greens (WA) amendment Nos 21 and 24.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —The Democrats will be supporting the Greens (WA) amendments. I understand these amendments amend the use of words `opposite sex partner' to recognise the de facto relationships of same sex couples. These amendments are consistent with the Australian Democrats proposal to have discrimination on the basis of sexuality outlawed—that is, removed from Commonwealth law. We believe it is unreasonable to disenfranchise persons in same sex relationships. Same sex couples are in large numbers in Australia and they contribute, as all other citizens, to taxes, laws, the running of our country, et cetera. They are entitled to the same consideration as couples of the opposite sex.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —Essentially the whole Social Security Act does not provide for same sex couples. To change it for one small splinter out of the whole Social Security Act would really make for an absurd situation. Maybe one day we will have that debate for the whole act. But to do it just here does not really help anyone.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—Not a good argument, Senator Neal. I can be relied upon to put this kind of amendment for just about every social security bill that comes through which deliberately discriminates against same sex couples. We could have changed half of the Social Security Act by now if we had had some support on this perfectly reasonable and rational proposal. If this means that if there is an opportunity in the future to have a multiple change—and I am not sure how you would actually effect a multiple change; perhaps it is possible—
—A private member's bill.
—And we have seen what has happened to private member's bills on sexuality—so far nothing, but we live in hope. Basically, I think it is perfectly reasonable to point the way where things can go and we all live in hope that the Labor Party, with the Greens and Democrats, will support sensible changes when those finally do come about in an all-inclusive way. Given that any of these social security changes do happen in a totally all-inclusive way, perhaps we might still work bit by bit and point the way. I would very much appreciate working with the 
 Labor Party for any ideas they have about a way that can be done en masse. Next time we come up with that proposal, I will look forward to their support.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—Given that the question was raised by Senator Neal, I would like to recognise, as I have done once or twice before in this debate and many other times on social security legislation, the potential problematic nature of having anomalies across the act. To that extent, I recognise the argument that Senator Neal has made. But if that is her sole problem with this amendment, I am quite sure, given that we do have other pieces of social security amending legislation coming up in this session, that an amendment could be provided to one of those future bills which ensures that this amendment, which Senator Margetts is putting forward here, does extend consistently across the entire act.
Perhaps Senator Neal would give some indication, if she has some support for the principle of what Senator Margetts is putting here, that she would be willing to support such an amendment and we could remove that whole problem of an anomaly that she is so concerned about at the moment. We could deal with that quickly now to save having to deal with it over an extended period the next time we deal with social security bills.
Requests not agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(22)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 128 (line 23), omit "2 years", substitute "12 months".
(23)	 Schedule 2, item 8 page 128 (line 26), omit "2 years", substitute "12 months".
(25)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 129 (line 21), omit "2 years", substitute "12 months".
(26)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 129 (line 25), omit "2 years", substitute "12 months or, in special circumstances determined by the Secretary, at least 6 months".
What we are dealing with here are changes in the definition of `youth allowance couple', so that a marriage-like relationship of 12 months or six months in special circumstances is recognised as a youth allowance couple. The 
 current provision is two years. I believe what we are suggesting is reasonable. If they have been in a marriage-like relationship for more than 12 months, we wonder what they are going to live on for the next year while they are waiting to be declared independent.
—I was just catching up on the fact that we had jumped Senator Stott Despoja's amendments.
—Senator Stott Despoja is not moving her amendments.
—At all?
—No. We are on Greens (WA) amendments 22, 23, 25 and 26.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Minister, I actually did not announce that I was withdrawing those amendments. That explains why people were not aware. I apologise for any confusion. I have withdrawn those amendments in favour of the Greens (WA) amendments. We agree with their proposal for a one-year waiting period, as opposed to those arrangements of two years set out in the bill. We will be supporting those amendments because we believe they are a reasonable compromise. I hope they will achieve and receive the support of the Senate.
I note for the record that it is not simple for those in the youth allowance categories to establish a marriage-like relationship, perhaps not as simple as it is for two people to go out and get married. Perhaps that is what the minister was suggesting earlier—that I was suggesting people would go off and get married. I am not. I am just hoping that the government's strict criteria and changed attitude to the independence of young unemployed does not convince young people to enter into such an arrangement out of desperation. Many of us have seen it happen.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Could I just explain, for the sake of the Senate, that this was the bringing together of two payments that had quite different eligibility in this area. We have tried to strike a balance whereby 
 young people on unemployment benefits, for instance, could have a de facto relationship declared from day one, whereas for young people on Austudy it would not have mattered how long they had a de facto relationship; it would not have affected their entitlement. That is why the government has brought it to two years—to try to meet the payments, if you like, halfway.
It was not through any attempt to make it very difficult for young people on the youth allowance. It was trying to bring together two payments and have something that was relatively consistent with somebody who is independent on the grounds of marriage. Two years we thought was a reasonable parallel. I would like to think marriage was going to be a great deal longer than two years.
—Are you accepting this?
—Yes, we will not oppose it, but I was trying to explain why we made it two years.
Requests agreed to.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(R10)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 140 (line 21), at the end of paragraph (a), add:
	 or  (iii)	 is under 21 years old and is an independent young person (see subsection 5(1)); or
			 (iv)	 is at least 21 years old and is living permanently and indefinitely away from the home of either or both of his or her parents;
The opposition is not proceeding with its original amendment No. 9. The new R10, which has been circulated, replaces the original amendment No. 9. The effect of this amendment is to extend the eligibility for rental assistance for two groups. The first group is the under 21 year olds. This is fairly strict criteria and I would not expect it to apply to a large number of people, but I think it is reasonable in the circumstances to allow for it—that is, where a person under 21 has been out of home for 18 weeks and has either been employed or registered as employed for 13 of those 18 weeks. The second category we are including is for those people over the 
 age of 21 years. If they are living permanently away from home then they should be eligible for rental assistance, in our view.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Rent assistance is available to all dependent young people who need to live away from their parents' home for educational training or because they are searching for employment or engaging in an activity that prepares them for employment—for example, voluntary work. That is talking about rent assistance being available to all dependent young people who need to live away from home for a variety of reasons, which I just listed. They are also entitled to rent assistance for safety reasons, because of exceptional circumstances in the parental household which pose a risk to the young person's physical or mental wellbeing.
Rent assistance is available to all independent young people who are living away from the parental home and to independent young people with partners and/or children who are living in their parents' home. I do not support the extension of rent assistance to young people who do not need to live away from home. To do so may encourage them to leave home unnecessarily. I believe that rent assistance should be directed to those young people who have no choice about incurring accommodation costs rather than to those who can choose to either live at home or away. For those reasons, the government will not support this amendment.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —I must say that this position the government is taking is really a bit extreme. To restrict it this much for people who are over 21 years old is probably taking it a bit far. I think it is not unreasonable that people over the age of 21 years who are in fact permanently living away from their parents' home should be entitled to rent assistance, and without having to establish that they have a need to. I think it is excessive in the circumstances to insist that adults over the age of 21 remain living with their parents.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text:
—I am just wondering whether the minister could address the point that was just made by Senator Neal. Say, for example, 
 there are mates of a young person who want to have another person in a flat in order to share the costs and it is nearer to the university than the home of the parents. What about that situation? Isn't that reasonable if there has been an agreement reached between the parents and the young man or woman? Does this legislation cater for that situation? Will this amendment go to that problem? It is not a problem but something that I would have thought happens quite frequently.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —Certainly, under this amendment anyone over 21 living away from their parents is covered. So anyone in the example you gave would be covered by this provision. Under the present provisions people in that situation would not be entitled to rent assistance, in my view—unless the minister has a different view.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The example that Senator Harradine gave would depend very much on whether the young person had to go away from home to study or whether it was simply a choice to move down to the next suburb to rent. If they had to go away to study then, of course, rent assistance would be applicable. If it was purely a question of personal choice then there is no reason why they are compelled to live at home but it would not be up to the taxpayer to support that choice. They would be seen to have an alternative to live at home. That is very much a question for families to decide rather than governments. The role of government is to decide that where there is a disadvantage to young people, for instance, from living a long way from their educational centre, then that is when rent assistance should be applicable, and it is under the legislation that we have.
If the young people are involved in a variety of activities, as I said earlier, if they are dependent and need to live away from their parents' home for education or training or because they are searching for employment or engaging in an activity that prepares them for employment, like voluntary work, then they would be eligible for rent assistance. If dependent young people had to live away from home for safety reasons because of 
 exceptionable circumstances in the parental household which posed a risk to the young person's physical and mental wellbeing then rent assistance would be applicable. It would also be applicable to independent young people living away from the parental home and to independent young people with partners or children who are living in their parents' home. For example, if a young, newly married couple with a child choose to live in the grandparents' home because it assists with child care, et cetera and reduces their living costs while one of the young parents is a student then they would be eligible for rent assistance.
We have tried to cover all the areas where one could reasonably justify the payment of the taxpayers' dollar. But if people are choosing voluntarily to incur rentals that they do not need to for study or for job search then that is something that needs to be financed by the young person themselves or by their family, not by the taxpayer. Certainly this amendment would open the door very widely to increased costs for taxpayers. It would circumvent the whole purpose of rent assistance, which is to be very much targeted to people who have a special eligibility for getting it. As it is, that is something like 88,000 young people, which is a very reasonable coverage compared with the present availability of rent assistance, which is only to those who are unemployed. The government has expanded the coverage of rent assistance so widely that to expand it any more widely would be financially irresponsible of the Senate. I see this amendment as opening the door very widely indeed.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—The Democrats will be supporting opposition amendment No. 10. We believe that this particular amendment has the effect of cutting out those young people who do need to live away from home to look for work. It maintains the proviso regarding education and training or job preparation but removes the section which states that the likelihood of a person getting employment will be significantly increased if the person 
 lives away from home. We support the amendment before us.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —I just emphasise to Senator Stott Despoja that the eligibility is there for somebody who has to move away from home to look for work.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The key words are `has to' move away from home. The nightmare continues: I will be supporting the opposition's amendment.
Request not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I will not be proceeding with the next amendment but the reason I raised it initially was out of curiosity. So instead of moving my amendment I ask the minister how the government can, on the one hand, refuse to recognise de facto relationships—initially, until we change the amendment—until they are more than two years standing while, on the other hand, penalise young people living in what the secretary determines as a marriage-like relationship with either or both the young people being below the age of consent? That is, having made that determination, how can the government then establish that those young persons' youth allowance rate shall be reduced to a level which would be payable if they were considered to have satisfied the youth allowance de facto relationship criteria? We thought it was rather strange that their youth allowance rate could be cut in some way.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The advice that I have received on Senator Stott Despoja's proposed request for amendment, which I understand she is now not proceeding with, is as follows: the request for amendment proposed by Senator Stott Despoja would remove a provision which has operated in the Social Security Act and for youth training allowance for some time.
The intention of the provision is to ensure that young people living in an illegal relationship, because they are under age, do not 
 benefit from the situation. It has been standard procedure to limit the rate for people in this situation to the rate they would receive if their relationship were legal. If the provisions were removed, young people living in a relationship which is not legally condoned would receive the higher single rate of payment and would not be subject to the partner income test—that is, they would be better off than young people in legal relationships. That is why the request for amendment is not acceptable to the government.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—As a matter of curiosity, the relationship itself is not illegal; it is only if their relationship involves sexual activities taking place. Isn't that correct?
—Under age.
—It is not actually illegal to be in a marriage-like relationship as long as you are not involved in sexual activities.
—Get real!
—The law is that you do not necessarily have to have a sexual element in your relationship to be `marriage-like'.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(19)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 135 (lines 1 to 9), omit Steps 10 and 11.
(20)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 135 (line 13), omit "Steps 8 and 10", substitute "Step 8".
(21)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 135 (line 17), omit "Steps 9 and 10", substitute "Step 9".
(22)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 135 (lines 19 to 26), omit paragraphs (c) and (d).
These requests for amendments remove the references in this particular section to the means test—in this case, steps 10 and 11 of the youth allowance rate calculator.
Further requests for amendments to be moved by the Democrats and the opposition will seek to remove additional references to the means test. I think some of these arguments were canvassed in second reading debates. It is on record what a debacle the operation of the means test has been as it applies under the Austudy regulations.
We have since had the Ombudsman's report and her conclusions as to some of the ridiculous provisions in that particular means testing arrangement and we seek to delete references to it.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —The Greens (WA) will be supporting Democrats requests for amendments Nos 19 to 22.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—For the record, the requests for amendments would mean that families able to minimise taxable income through partnerships, trusts and self-employment would again qualify for welfare, although well able to provide for the support of their children. Youth allowance already provides that the AMT will not apply to independent young people.
I do not know that there is any virtue in pursuing this. Certainly, the government is not happy to accept requests for amendments on this subject. It is very important that there not be an opportunity to rort the system that the taxpayer is paying for.
Requests not agreed to.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(27)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 141 (after line 21) to page 142 (before line 1), column 3 of table items 1, 4, 5, 6 and 7, omit "$71.60", substitute "$55.75".
At present, the rent assistance threshold rate, that is, the amount a person would have to pay in rent before receiving any rent assistance, is set at 21 per cent for most social security payments. However, as an anomaly, to make it more complex for the bureaucrats—and, of course, we do not want to do that—it is set for 27 per cent for the youth allowance. That means a person who is on youth allowance has to pay more before they are eligible for rent assistance. This request for amendment makes the youth allowance threshold 21 per cent. That actually makes it consistent with social security payments.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The govern 
 ment is not disposed to support this request for amendment. Rent assistance is targeted to those who must pay higher rents. Young people who would benefit from the proposed request for amendment are those with more manageable housing costs. In general, these young people are paying less than 30 per cent of their incomes in rent. This bill will improve housing affordability for young people and provide them with more choices in terms of type and location of accommodation.
I know that it may stick in the throats of some of the minor parties, but one of the major benefits of this legislation is that so many students—70,000—are expected to benefit by up to a maximum of $37.40 a week by gaining access to rent assistance for the first time. Around 350 young unemployed people aged 16 and 17 years will benefit by up to an average of $18 a week because of access to rent assistance. Those are important measures which should not be dismissed lightly. The proposal by Senator Margetts is simply not supported.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—There you go, Minister, confusing the bureaucrats again. You are inconsistent in your call for consistency. In this particular instance, I am a bit surprised as to why you say that the housing costs are more affordable for young people. They may be forced into more affordable housing, but I have not actually seen ads which say, `If you are under 24, you will get this housing at a cheaper rate.' In fact, I have not seen that at all. I am suggesting that it is reasonable for those either on social security or youth allowance to have the same threshold.
Request not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(23)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 143 (lines 10 to 15), omit paragraphs (a) and (b) (and the colon preceding paragraph (a)), substitute "Rate B for the person worked out using column 4".
This request relates to rent assistance. I want to make the point to the Minister for Social 
 Security that we are not upset about the idea of rent assistance being extended to students. We have commended it at every opportunity, but we have pointed out certain ironies along the way, including the fact that last year this government made a number of cuts to rent assistance entitlements, including the cut in relation to people living in shared accommodation—a cut by one-third. This is something which this particular amendment seeks to redress in relation to the rate of rent assistance specifically for single people in shared accommodation.
I understand that the Greens (WA) will be moving a similar request. I will not hold up the debate, but I was curious to hear the minister's comments earlier about what was defined as reasonable rental costs for a young person on common youth allowance. Is it that the government is defining as reasonable the amount of rent assistance that is provided for accommodation? We strongly opposed at the time the cuts to rent assistance. We maintain that opposition. We seek to redress, by way of the request before the chamber, the cuts that have been made to rent assistance entitlements.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—This is another double whammy for young people. As Senator Stott Despoja pointed out, Democrats request 23 is the same as Greens (WA) request 28. What we are seeking to do is remove the provision that those in shared housing receive only two-thirds of the maximum rent assistance otherwise payable. This impacts specifically on students.
We believe there is a problem in that the two-third rate for sharers is already affecting those on Newstart and other dole payments. The Greens (WA) spoke up strongly at the time because of the fact that we were aware that the only way for many people to survive was to share the same accommodation. That was the reality for many people struggling to survive in society. The government is trying to ensure that people have to live on their own in order to get full rent assistance. It is saying that students living in shared accommodation will receive only two-thirds of the maximum rent assistance otherwise payable. 
 I am not sure where the logic is, except to reduce the payout for those people needing assistance.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I am always a bit loath to make changes for one particular group of people. I guess, to some extent, this could be argued to be one of those situations.
—What would you do about the 21 to—
—Let me finish; you might be happy. This is a circumstance where I am prepared to take that step, bearing in mind there may be some difficulties with consistency, particularly because young people—whether they be students or unemployed—are probably the largest single group of people who share accommodation.
I remember when this particular item went through for everybody. It did not seem entirely logical because you are restricted in your access to rental assistance by the fact that you have to be spending a minimum on rent before you can even access it. That already cuts out a vast majority of young people. I cannot see why they should be cut out just because they are sharing. It could impact quite severely on the group of people covered by the youth allowance. Because this particular group will be more affected than anyone else, I think this anomaly is justified.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Let me make it perfectly clear: the government is not prepared to accept a change to the rent assistance measure which went through the parliament just over a year ago. It is a very fair and equitable measure when you look at the comparison between how couples getting rent assistance are placed even by comparison now with the sharers. Two single people sharing are still substantially better off in terms of the rent assistance that is coming into that household compared with a couple. It was entirely out of kilter before.
You are adding complexity to the system. That is exactly what you are doing in a huge way. You are also adding substantially to the revenue implications. After the long debate that we had in this place a year or so ago, I 
 find it extraordinary that you would be prepared to take this step. There is no way that the government would be prepared to accept this. I find it amazing that you would try to overturn something which is established. As you said, the measure that was introduced goes very much to young people sharing, and there are a whole lot of reasons for them taking this preferred option.
The revenue implications would be substantial. I do not think I have them here tonight, but I make it very clear that we would not be prepared to add to the cost of the youth allowance package, which involves spending over several years, by opening up this door and changing the rent assistance sharers rate that you are proposing.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —We were opposed to this move when it first came in a year ago. We argued strongly against it. I remember you putting exactly the same argument then as you do now, which is somehow that there is a comparison between couples sharing and single people sharing. The obvious difference I would have thought the minister would be aware of is that generally couples share a room and they have to pay only for that one room. People who are single do not share the same room generally, unless they are in particularly desperate circumstances. As such, they have to pay for accommodation that provides additional rooms for each person. To say that they are the same circumstances is completely untrue.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Just briefly, I take issue with the minister's claim that this somehow makes this more complex. I accept the minister's claim that this adds expense; of course it does. But it does not necessarily make it more complex. Indeed, we believe that it makes it more fair, and we did oppose this. Just because it has been mandated or legislated, or whatever you might say, by the parliament previously does not mean we thought it was necessarily a good decision by this place. Indeed, the Democrats and others were outraged by the cuts to rent assistance occurring at the same time the government insisted on boasting about its budget measures 
 and the proposed introduction of a common youth allowance, which did extend rent assistance.
I just find it extraordinary and quite hypocritical, on the one hand, to be boasting about extensions in rent assistance and, on the other hand, to be cutting back on the amount available to certain groups—and groups that, I might suggest, are often in the least position to get quality and affordable, and perhaps convenient, housing. Once again, I think we are just hitting hardest at those least able to afford it. So I see this, as the bill currently stands, as quite a retrograde provision. I seek in these requests to make it fairer in terms of the amount available to those people in shared accommodation.
Request not agreed to.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(24)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 157 (line 19), omit paragraph 1067G-F22(a), substitute:
(a)	 the relevant AWOTE; and
(25)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 157 (after line 21), after point 1067G-F22, insert:
1067G-F22A 	 For the purposes of this Module, the  relevant AWOTE  means the amount that, under the heading "Trends and Estimates" in the document entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia", published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in January in the year of income, is specified as being the full time ordinary earnings for Australia for the quarter to which the document relates.
These requests relate to the parental income-free area for the purposes of this section. The Democrats seek to change the amount specified of $23,400 in terms of the income testing arrangements by inserting the relevant AWOTE—that is, average weekly ordinary times earning. We think this is a fairer definition. I understand that the Greens (WA) have a comparable request for amendment.
As I say, we think this is one way of perhaps alleviating the harshness of one of the 
 measures in this bill, and that is income test arrangements that kick in at an unusually—and I think unfair—early period. So this is an attempt to perhaps raise that threshold in some way. Also I think it is not only economically but legislatively quite fair and appropriate that it is matched with the relevant average weekly ordinary times earning.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—As Senator Stott Despoja has indicated, in terms of the actual starting amount the Greens (WA) amendment seeks to achieve the same effect as the Democrats' amendment. The Democrats' amendment is linked to the average weekly ordinary time earnings index, which we believe makes it preferable to our amendment, which deals with a figure of $36,000. The current level is such that, even if only one parent is in employment, nearly 90 per cent of full-time adult workers are earning too much for their children to receive the full benefit. So, in some ways, it makes a bit of a farce of averages.
Given that it is commonplace for both parents to be in paid employment, the test should reflect this fact. We could be talking about one partner who is on the wages of an unskilled labourer—let us just say $25,000—and the other one may be engaged in casual cleaning; and they could very easily get up to $36,000. We are not talking about rich people. The test should not adversely affect families in low to middle socioeconomic classes. They are exactly the people the government should be targeting in terms of higher education.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I would just indicate that the opposition has a similar amendment, although I suppose it is a bit more restrictive in that it applies only to the means test applied to parents of unemployed young people rather than students. I would indicate that we will be supporting this amendment, and we will persist with ours only if this amendment fails.
Essentially, we believe that the means test commencing at $23,400 is too low. Certainly I do not believe that a family on such an income would have sufficient left over to support what is essentially another adult. This would mean that you are expected to support 
 three adults on an income of $23,400. I think that is far too strict. Also, I think the average weekly earnings—or the AWOTE, as they now call it—is probably a more appropriate level at which the payment should start cutting out.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I can understand that Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja might like to play around with this. But I find it breathtaking in the extreme to discover that Senator Neal—whose government was perfectly content with a threshold of $23,400 for families with two, three, et cetera, students—somehow finds it difficult to accept when it also applies to those same children during a period of their unemployment—
—They are not children.
—They are children in the sense that they are financially dependent upon their parents. I am happy to say `young people' if you would like me to. But the reality is that your government considered $23,400 a perfectly reasonable threshold for the purposes of Austudy. Now that is translated for the purposes of youth allowance, which means for students and for the young unemployed—and sometimes they will be one and the same person, and sometimes they will be separate.
I find it incredible that the opposition would somehow find $23,400 all of a sudden to be an unacceptable threshold level. You know as well as I do that this means test for youth allowance is in fact slightly more generous than the one that you have had all this time for Austudy. So I find it just beyond belief, Senator. It is more to be expected perhaps from people who have not been in government and are not likely to be in government, where the cost of their promises does not count. But I warn you that you will be held accountable for the cost of amendments that you make of this type.
Let me just make it clear the sorts of thing we are talking about. To increase the parental income threshold to either the level suggested by Senator Margetts, $36,000, or to the level suggested by Senator Stott-Despoja, $34,000 or $37,000, depending on which AWOTE is 
 used, would add over $100 million per annum to the cost of the program. If you are authorised to go out endorsing that sort of expenditure, we will be asking Mr Beazley next where the money is coming from.
This measure would not assist families most in need, that is, those with incomes below $23,400, because they are already completely provided for. You are trying to protect families with income in excess of $76,000 a year and allow them to a receive some assistance if they have two children living away from home. The current youth allowance parental income threshold applies also to Austudy and to the above minimum family allowance, and it seems strange that in all those years in government you found it was perfectly acceptable. Let me tell you that if you limited it simply to the unemployed, as you were talking about, I understand from the briefing note I have got here that it would be $30 million of expenditure purely for the unemployed, and it would be $70 million for students. I urge you to give serious consideration—
—Can you repeat those figures, please?
—Certainly. The extra expenditure from either of these two measures proposed by Senator Margetts and Senator Stott-Despoja would be in the order of $30 million of extra expenditure for the unemployed and $70 million for students.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text: —I am always willing to be helpful. I suggest that the Greens (WA) are perfectly willing to vote for the wind-down of some of the very large amounts of corporate welfare under the diesel fuel rebate scheme to help you out with the money.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —I have a question for the minister. Does the minister not expect any families to be adversely affected by this particular parental means threshold? Is that the case?

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—The reality is that, although it is the same starting point 
 as for Austudy, because of a number of other entitlements that come with this reform of the youth allowance, most families will not in fact have any impact on their means test until they are in the vicinity of $30,000. I will not say none, but I would say to you that that is the advice I have received, that, where theoretically, on paper, it will cut in at $23,400, because of the additional money that comes into that family's hands for some of these complementary measures in this package, that is where it would really start to reduce on the basis of one dollar for every four dollars.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —Looking at the government estimates before me, there are 33,600 18- to 20-year-olds who will have reduced payments as a consequence of being judged dependent on their parental income, as a result of being parentally means tested, until they achieve or meet the independent criteria. So 33,600 will be adversely affected, at least.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I confirm the figure of 33,600.
	 Question put:
	 That the requests (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—by leave—I move:
The the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
(10A)	 Schedule 2, item 8 page 157 (line 19), omit paragraph 1067G-F22(a), substitute:
		 (a)	 if the person:
			 (i)	 is undertaking full-time study (see section 541B)—$23,400; or
			 (ii)	 is not undertaking full-time study—average weekly earnings multiplied by 52; and
(10B)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 157 (after line 21), after point 1067G-F22, insert:
		 1067G-F22A	 For the purposes of this module,  average weekly earnings  means average weekly earnings (full-time adult employees ordinary time earnings) specified in the document entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia", publication number 6302.0, as published by the Australian Statistician most recently before 1 January in the current calendar year.
These requests were foreshadowed in the previous debate. They request that the means test for the parents of unemployed young 
 people should be raised from $23,400 to average weekly earnings, which is presently $36,000 but obviously that figure will vary. These requests attempt to soften and to apply more fairly the means test for what the government has been describing as `unemployed children'—but, in fact, being over the age of 18 years they are unemployed adults. I understand that the children of adults are always `the children of' but, in common usage, the term `children' is not normally defined as a person over the age of 18 years. We are probably all clear on the effect of the amendments, so I will not speak further.
Requests not agreed to.
—We now move to opposition amendment No. 11 on sheet 864. There was a Greens (WA) amendment which, as I understand it, has been withdrawn in favour of the Democrats amendment.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —There was an understanding between the opposition and the government in relation to amendment 11. The opposition was going to withdraw this on the basis that the government gave an undertaking to put what is called the module into the legislation itself. Maybe the minister would like to make a statement to that effect.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—Yes, I confirm that. That was the agreement and that is what the government will do.
—With that agreement in place, the opposition is withdrawing that amendment. I understand that that is so for Democrats amendment No. 26 and the Greens (WA) amendment.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I seek clarification. My understanding is that the effect of the Democrats, Greens (WA) and the opposition amendments was to delete references to the actual means test. My understanding is the effect of the agreement that the opposition has just reached with the government is for inclusion of the module—it is not actually 
 deleting references. Can someone enlighten me if I am wrong?
—Senator Neal or Senator Newman, would you like to throw some light on the subject?
—I am sorry; I missed that.
—Senator Stott Despoja raised a question with regard to the opposition agreement reached with the government that allowed for the withdrawal of your amendment 11.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —Minister, I understand that we have agreed—Senator Neal can confirm this, I hope—that, while the actual means test requirements are in regulations, they will be put into the consequential amendment bill when it comes before the Senate.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text:
—I do not think it was agreed exactly when it would come in, but I assume that the next most convenient time is with the consequential amendments so that it would be incorporated within the legislation itself.
—It would be as soon as it is possible.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(26)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 159 (line 20) to page 160 (line 22), omit Module G.
My understanding from the reading of my amendment is that it is not inconsistent with what has just taken place. My amendment seeks to omit module G in relation to the family actual means test. I will proceed with that amendment. I will not engage in debate if that facilitates progress.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—I state here that I will be supporting Democrats amendment 26. It has the same effect as Senator Margetts's amendment.
Request not agreed to.
—On behalf of Senator Margetts, I will move her amendment.
—Senator Brown, just to save you some time, I have been advised that it is an identical amendment. It has been disposed of and you cannot move it again.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—At this point, may I ask a question of the minister about the amendments that we have just dealt with because it has a bearing on where we are going?
—You can certainly ask the minister a question.
—Senator Neal might also answer this. On the running sheet, it says the opposition amendment which was agreed to was to omit module G.
—No.
—Was that withdrawn?
—Senator Brown, opposition amendment No. 11 that you are referring to was not moved, on the basis of an agreement that was reached between the government and the opposition. Senator Stott Despoja decided then to proceed with her amendment, which was lost. Democrats amendment No. 26 and Greens (WA) amendment No. 30 are identical. The reason I said to you that you cannot move it is for that reason.
—Chair, your understanding is exactly the same as mine. Thank you.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—I am not proceeding with an amendment; I am actually asking in the committee stage for clarification from the minister, or indeed from Senator Neal. I want to clarify the intent of what you have organised in terms of the module. You are actually seeking to have it—
Senator Neal interjecting—
—You do not want me to ask that question? Perhaps I could ask the minister, then. My understanding is that you have just arranged for this amendment in relation to module G to be dealt with in a different way—essentially, it is the module that provides for the actual means test. So you are not objecting, as such, to the 
 actual means test and its operation in the context of the common youth allowance? So you are not objecting to the application of the AMT to the CYA; you would just prefer the module to be somewhere else?

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —We did object and, as you might recall, we actually moved amendments to it. Unfortunately, we were unsuccessful. Putting that aside, we think it is preferable to have it incorporated in the act rather than to have it separate so that people are aware of what is contained and there can be some certainty. It is not our preferred position but it deals with some problems that we see in the present act.

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text:
—Thank you for that explanation. With all due respect, I make the point that the amendments we have just dealt with would have had a similar effect to those amendments we dealt with previously; that is, in relation to deleting references to the actual means test. May I suggest, and I am not sure whether this procedurally is unfounded, that had my amendment, which was identical to the Greens (WA) amendment, succeeded in relation to deleting references to the actual means test, we would have taken on board consequential amendments that would have done the same thing in the relevant and other sections of this bill.
I do not accept, as an excuse, the fact that the amendment previously was not supported by the opposition because the amendments that we dealt with earlier in the committee stage in relation to AMT were not successful. I am sure that had mine been successful we could have gone back and fixed up the rest. I just wanted to get on record who was and who was not supporting the actual means test.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text:
—I think Senator Stott Despoja sees something nasty in the wood pile—there is not. Could I just go through the items now and see whether Senator Neal nods her head that she is in agreement with what I am saying, because this is the true source of events. Module G stays in the legislation because it empowers us to use an actual means test. Very soon, as 
 soon as we possibly can, we will be tabling regulations in the Senate to implement that. Then, as soon as practicable, we will incorporate the regulations into the legislation. Did you understand that—and, in spite of all that, you said all that?

name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
text: —No, I understand that. I was interested in getting on record the rationale for the opposition's agreement and decision to withdraw their amendment. No, I understand what is happening. We just have a different philosophical position on the actual means test and whether or not it should stay, regardless of where it should stay, in the legislation. I was just trying to clarify what the opposition had actually achieved through their amendment. We disagree with the actual means test. That is the point I am making, Senator Neal, and you guys obviously do not do so.

name: Neal, Sen Belinda
text: —It is not our position. We have attempted to deal with the matters relating to the means test on separate occasions. There are three or four different amendments that have dealt with that issue. This is a different aspect of it. Whatever the means test is, or is not—and we have debated that already—we think it should be in the act so people are aware of it. It is quite a separate issue.
