To try to say that because we want it to be contained in the act we support it as it now stands is really unfair and dishonest; and I really wish you would stop saying it.

name: Harradine, Sen Brian
text: —As I understand it, this matter can be the subject of debate when the consequential legislation comes forward. There is nothing to stop us having a fairly fulsome debate on the AMT at that particular stage. That is as I see it, but I might be wrong.

name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
text: —When the regulations come into the Senate there will be another occasion as well.

name: Woodley, Sen John
text:
—by leave—I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments: 

(1)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 149 (line 12), after "1067G-E18", insert "1067G-E18A".
(2)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 149 (line 18), after "business", insert "which includes the provision of professional services".
(3)	 Schedule 2, item 8, page 149 (after line 27), after point 1067G-E18, insert:
Interest in business assets when business includes carrying on of primary production.
1067-E18A Subject to point 1067G-E19, 100% of the value of a person's interest in the assets of a business which includes the carrying on of primary production is disregarded if the person, or his or her partner, is wholly or mainly engaged in the business and the business:
	 (a)	 is owned by the person; or
	 (b)	 is carried on by a partnership of which the person is a member; or
	 (c)	 is carried on by a company of which the person is a member; or
	 (d)	 is carried on by the trustee of a trust in which the person is a beneficiary.
This is not the first occasion that I have moved these amendments. I was saying that, in fact, these are amendments that I have moved before on many occasions, including when the current position of seating in the chamber was the reverse to what it is now. In fact, on a number of occasions over the years colleagues of mine have moved similar amendments. They are amendments which attempt to help farm families. Senators will know that the current government are friends of farmers and so, no doubt, now that they are in government rather than in opposition, they will be prepared to look very kindly on this amendment which was defeated on a number of occasions over the years when there was a different government in the Senate.
It is to do with Austudy, particularly the assets test for farming families. Senators will know that, as the proposed youth allowance replaces Austudy for students under 25 years of age, this again brings into the debate the issue that under the Austudy assets test farmers can discount the value of their farms by 50 per cent. That is already in place. I note that under the new arrangements this 50 per cent discount is to be retained. I must say that I was really quite amazed at that. If my amendments 1, 2 and 3 are not passed then in amendment No.4 I will be happy to remind 
 the government of their promise during the last election.	However, I am trying to achieve a little bit more than the government promised. I am actually trying to achieve what they agreed to prior to the election, when they were in opposition.
I refer the committee to a report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee dated March 1995. It was a report on an inquiry into the impact of assets tests on farming families access to social security and Austudy. It was quite an extensive inquiry. It was held over eight months and it received 250 very substantial submissions. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy gave evidence that about 5,400 students from farming families were being denied Austudy because of the assets test. Just to remind the Senate, the problem is that many farms have a book value which is quite high but, certainly over recent years, those same farms have had negative or very low incomes.
Yet despite the fact that there have been farmers who for years have been struggling even to put food on the table, their children have not been able to access Austudy in order to continue their education because the assets test—the book value of the farm—has ruled them out. The phrase that is used so often is that they are asset rich and income poor. The report states:
The Committee, however, considers that the assets test applied to farming families in order to determine eligibility for AUSTUDY, is an inappropriate policy instrument that does not take into account the nature of farm assets and their relationship with income.
The majority recommendation of the committee was that farm assets should be excluded from the Austudy assets test. This recommendation was signed by the Chairman, Senator Brownhill, and also by Senators Calvert, Crane, Troeth and me.
The amendments that I am moving tonight will implement that recommendation of the committee report, that is, to exempt the farm assets from the Austudy assets test. I have moved them in confidence that the government will agree to them, as there was such strong support from those particular members 
 of the government, when they were in opposition, for the report of the Senate's Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee. At least on this matter the Labor Party has been consistent in that they did not agree with that report. I presume they still do not agree.
Progress reported.

name: Tambling, Sen Grant
text:
—Defence support is now one of the four major industries of the Northern Territory. At a time of increasing political instability, it is salutary to focus on our defence assets in northern Australia. The Army Presence in the North project, the APIN project, stems from the 1987 defence white paper, Defence of Australia , and commenced in 1992 with the relocation of an armoured reconnaissance regiment to Darwin. It is a task of national importance and will significantly change the thrust of Australia's defence, particularly with the emphasis and priority given in recent years by the Howard government and the ministers Ian McLachlan and Bronwyn Bishop.
APIN involves the relocation to Darwin of approximately 2,300 personnel, 200 armoured fighting vehicles, including Leopard tanks, ASLAV light armoured vehicles and M113 armoured personnel carriers and 500 support vehicles. A total of $850 million is to be spent on infrastructure development and relocation activities over the 10-year period from 1992. By the year 2001, Australian Defence Force numbers in the Northern Territory will stand at over 4,400. The total Defence Force `family', including dependants, will number well in excess of 10,000 people.
In addition to APIN, there are many other exciting defence related activities taking place in the Northern Territory that will have a significant beneficial impact on the local economy and population, which I will get to shortly. Major focuses for APIN in 1998 
 include the completion of APIN stage 1, which is scheduled to be completed in the first half of 1998. This will see capital works costing $198 million finished, with most of the work completed at Robertson Barracks. APIN stage 1 includes new or additional facilities being built for the following units: Headquarters 1st Brigade, 1st Armoured Regiment of the Royal Australian Armoured Corps, 104th Signal Squadron of the Royal Australian Signals, the 161st Reconnaissance Squadron, Headquarters Army Support Unit Darwin and the 7th Training Group. There will be some additional facilities for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment.
There will also be the important opening in May 1998 of a 70-place defence child-care facility at Fairway Waters, a suburb of Palmerston, greatly expanding child-care places available to all Palmerston residents. Palmerston is now the fastest growing town in Australia. It is adjacent to Robertson Barracks and is a satellite city in its own right of Darwin.
APIN stage 2, which will cost $268 million, is proceeding and expected to take until the year 2000 or 2001 to complete. In 1998 there will be the biggest single move north under APIN. The 5th/7th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment of the 1st Brigade, will be relocated from Sydney to Darwin. As the mechanised infantry battalion of the 1st Brigade, 5/7 RAR is a key component and is the largest unit in the brigade. It has a current strength of 518 soldiers and is not expected to exceed 540 this year.
Due to the fact that 5/7 RAR is a combat unit, it is an all male organisation and currently comprises 326 single soldiers and 192 married members. Approximately 675 dependants will be moving to Darwin with the soldiers of the 5/7 RAR. This important link and relocation is very important because Territorians have embraced this integration of defence families into the social infrastructure of the community, and the extra residents and expenditure they generate underpin programs in housing, health, education and recreation. I know and can say confidently that Territorians openly welcome ADF personnel and their families into the community. Additionally, the 
 capital works program spending of $143 million this year is very much alive. Additionally, we have the participation of personnel in defence exercises.
Based on these figures, a total of almost 1,200 people will be moving to Darwin and Palmerston in late 1998 and early 1999. Defence has worked very hard to ensure that the move will go as smoothly as possible and that integration takes place carefully. With the experience to draw on the move north of the 1st Armoured Regiment and the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, Defence do not anticipate any problems and there is excellent cooperation with the Northern Territory Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry, in particular their Defence and Space Industries Group.
The Australian Defence Force will also ensure, through a community integration committee, that people will assimilate well into the community. It is a credit to the Northern Territory government that it is the first state government to create a ministry of defence support, and I note it is held by the Chief Minister. The Defence Force realises the importance of a soldier's family settling in and is taking great lengths to make sure this happens in the Top End.
In 1998 infrastructure developments will be extended and relate to fields such as the Bradshaw Field Training Area. Fifty-four million dollars has been approved to develop Bradshaw, an 8,710 square kilometre property 600 kilometres south-west of Darwin, into a live fire and manoeuvring area to be used primarily by 1st Brigade. Approximately $14 million will be spent in 1998 on Bradshaw, with the remainder being spent through to the year 2000.
At RAAF Darwin expenditure of $10 million this financial year will take place. This will see work continue on the $60 million development of operational facilities that include the provision of ordnance loading aprons for 10 FA18 or F111 aircraft, an operational and technical support facility, a base command post, additional fuel storage, a rescue and firefighting facility, and associated civil works and engineering services.
At RAAF Tindal, whose personnel did such an excellent job recently in the Katherine flood disaster, work on stage 4 of development will proceed. About $13.5 million will be spent this year out of a budget of $31 million for the whole of stage 4. This will see the completion of facilities much like those described for RAAF Base Darwin with additional deployment accommodation and apron extensions. In Alice Springs a tremendous amount of work is being carried on for infrastructure development associated with the joint defence facility of Pine Gap. Total defence capital works spending in the Territory for 1997-98 is $143 million, an increase of $37 million over 1996-97 and a significant part of the annual defence expenditure of $385 million for the 1997-98 financial year.
The Defence Force's annual program of exercises will also take place, and personnel from Australia, New Zealand, the United States, Singapore and Indonesia will participate in Australian Defence Force exercises in the Northern Territory. It is estimated that some 5,500 personnel will take part in exercises in 1998 and approximately half will be ADF personnel not normally based in the Northern Territory—a complementary exercise to Northern Territory tourism. This is another boost of tens of millions of dollars into the Northern Territory economy.
In 1999, Exercise Crocodile 99, a replacement for the Kangaroo exercises, will take place in the Territory. Planning has commenced for this very significant operation.
There is also significant economic benefit for Darwin and the rest of the Territory derived from visiting warships. Already this year six large vessels have stopped over in Darwin. These have included USS Peleliu, USS Juneau, USS Blue Ridge, USS Fife, USS Port Royal and USS Curtis Wilbur. They carried in total over 5,300 sailors, and the length of their stays varied from a couple of days to a week. At a very conservative estimate, these visits have injected $5 million into the Northern Territory economy.
I believe the importance of defence to the Northern Territory cannot be overstated. I have described many examples in 1998 alone which will result in massive injections of cash 
 and capital works into the Territory economy. There is also the fact that ADF personnel are now an integral part of the Territory's communities. I think it could safely be said that in past years many defence personnel based in the Territory left their hearts down south and returned to what they viewed as home after their stint in the north was finished. I do not believe this is now the case.
The extension of time of people living in the north will be a credit to both the Defence Force and the Territory community. The majority of ADF personnel based in the Territory are there for the long term, and I believe they will view the Territory always as home. Their unstinting and selfless service in the Katherine flood disaster shows just how much a part of the community the ADF have become.
